      "sfinstructionsc" : "<span style=\"font-family: calibri,sans-serif;\"><span style=\"font-size: 11.0pt;\">My company has already has a signed Purchase Order for Coveo training classes.  How should I register for a training class? through the on-line help?<br><br>Yes, you can register for a class via the <a href=\"http://www.coveo.com/en/services/training\" target=\"_blank\">Coveo Training Portal</a> once a signed and returned purchase order (PO) is in place.  You can select each of the relevant courses to register for that are covered in the PO. <br><br>The process is as follows:<br><br>1.    Go to the <a href=\"http://www.coveo.com/en/services/training\" target=\"_blank\">Training Page</a> on our website to see a list of all the training offerings and pricing with recommended learning paths by specialty or role.<br>2.    Select the individual class you wish to register for which will take you to the detailed page that includes the description and agenda.<br>3.    Select “View Schedule” to see a list of dates we will be delivering that class virtually.<br>4.    Select the date by clicking the Register button and fill out the registration form with your contact information.  <br>5.    You can close your browser after this because you have pre-paid for training.<br>6.    Once you submit your contact information, we get a notification and the Coveo Training team will mark you as paid because you already pre-paid for the training.<br>7.    Once you are marked as paid, an automated email is sent to you that contains a link to join the class and instructions.  The confirmation email also contains a link to add the class time to your calendar.<br><br>All classes are priced per person.  <br><br>Here is a short <a href=\"https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=ytckDuszPF0&amp;feature=youtu.be\" target=\"_blank\">video</a> that steps you through the registration process as well.  You can ignore the last step on paying with a credit card if you have pre-paid training funds from a signed PO.</span></span><br><br><br> <br> ",

signed Purchase Order for Coveo training classes. \\u00a0How should I register for a training class? through the on-line help?<br><br>Yes, you can register for a class via the <a href=\\\"http://www.coveo.com/en/services/training\\\" target=\\\"_blank\\\">Coveo Training Portal</a> once a signed and returned purchase order (PO) is in place.\\u00a0 You can select each of the relevant courses to register for that are covered in the PO.\\u00a0<br><br>The process is as follows:<br><br>1.\\u00a0\\u00a0 \\u00a0Go to the <a href=\\\"http://www.coveo.com/en/services/training\\\" target=\\\"_blank\\\">Training Page</a> on our website to see a list of all the training offerings and pricing with recommended learning paths by specialty or role.<br>2.\\u00a0\\u00a0 \\u00a0Select the individual class you wish to register for which will take you to the detailed page that includes the description and agenda.<br>3.\\u00a0\\u00a0 \\u00a0Select \\u201cView Schedule\\u201d to see a list of dates we will be delivering that class virtually.<br>4.\\u00a0\\u00a0 \\u00a0Select the date by clicking the Register button and fill out the registration form with your contact information. \\u00a0<br>5.\\u00a0\\u00a0 \\u00a0You can close your browser after this because you have pre-paid for training.<br>6.\\u00a0\\u00a0 \\u00a0Once you submit your contact information, we get a notification and the Coveo Training team will mark you as paid because you already pre-paid for the training.<br>7.\\u00a0\\u00a0 \\u00a0Once you are marked as paid, an automated email is sent to you that contains a link to join the class and instructions.\\u00a0\\u00a0The confirmation email also contains a link to add the class time to your calendar.<br><br>All classes are priced per person. This is advanced settings<br><br>* Not available via the UI. \\u00a0Needs to be added into the <a href=\\\"https://developers.coveo.com/pages/releaseview.action?pageId=18350826\\\" target=\\\"_blank\\\">QPL</a> manually.</p>\\n\\n<p>Some options for the <a href=\\\"https://developers.coveo.com/display/public/SearchREST/REST+Search+API+Models\\\" target=\\\"_blank\\\">Search API</a> can only be activated/changed\\u00a0through the QPL<br><br><b>Example #1:\\u00a0</b><br>topClicks exportOffset: &quot;P1D&quot;, exportPeriod: &quot;P3M&quot;, refreshRate: &quot;P1W&quot;, searchEventFilter: &quot;originlevel1==&#39;SearchPortal&#39;&quot;, matchAdvancedQuery: true, modifier: 1000<br><br>Story:\\u00a0<br>Relevance tuning model is gathering 3 months of query and click data excluding today\\u2019s date. Model is refreshed each week. We only use the Search Portal hub activity for this model. \\u00a0The 5 best top clicks should be at the top with a score of 1000<br><br><br><b>Example #2:\\u00a0</b><br>topClicks exportOffset: &quot;P1D&quot;, exportPeriod: &quot;P1W&quot;, refreshRate: &quot;P1D&quot;, searchEventFilter: &quot;originlevel1==&#39;SearchPortal&#39;&#39;&quot;, modifier: 1000<br><br>Story:\\u00a0<br>Relevance tuning model is gathering 1 week of queries and click data excluding today\\u2019s date. Model is refreshed each day. We only use the Search Portal hub activity for this model. \\u00a0The 5 best top clicks should be at the top with a score of 1000.<br><br><b>Example #3:\\u00a0</b><br>topClicks exportOffset: &quot;P1D&quot;, searchEventFilter: &quot;(originlevel1==&#39;External Search&#39; OR originlevel1==&#39;Internal Search&#39;) AND (documenturl=@&#39;/coveo/&#39;)&quot;, exportPeriod: &quot;P1M&quot;, refreshRate: &quot;P1D&quot;, modifier: 250, customModelParameters: [&quot;--conf&quot;, &quot;coveo.drill.filterFields=&quot;]<br><br>Story:\\u00a0<br>Relevance tuning model is gathering 1 month of queries and click data excluding today\\u2019s date. Model is refreshed each day. We use activity from two hubs (External and Internal) to create this model. We only gather top clicks where the document URL contains /coveo/. The customModelParameters setting ignores the hub names when creating the model which allows the top clicks to be used in the results in both hubs.\\u00a0<br><br><b>Example #4:\\u00a0</b><br>topClicks commonFilter: &quot;(originlevel1 IN [\\\\&quot;CaseCreate\\\\&quot;,\\\\&quot;Customer_Search\\\\&quot;])&quot;, searchEventFilter: &quot;(originlevel1 IN [\\\\&quot;CaseCreate\\\\&quot;,\\\\&quot;Customer_Search\\\\&quot;])&quot;, customEventFilter: &quot;(originlevel1 IN [\\\\&quot;CaseCreate\\\\&quot;,\\\\&quot;Customer_Search\\\\&quot;])&quot;, exportPeriod: &quot;P3M&quot;, refreshRate: &quot;P1W&quot;, modifier: 250, matchQuery: false, matchAdvancedQuery: true, useRefinedQuery: true, customModelParameters: [&quot;--conf&quot;, &quot;coveo.drill.userContextFields.0=c_context_product&quot;, &quot;--conf&quot;,&quot;coveo.drill.userContextPrefix=badprefix&quot;,&quot;--conf&quot;, &quot;coveo.drill.filterFields=&quot; ]<br><br>Story:\\u00a0<br>Relevance tuning model is gathering 3 months of queries and clicks data. Model is refreshed each week. This model was built for a case creation page with the feature of long query(lq). We use two hubs (CaseCreate and Customer Search) to create this model. The customModelParameters setting coveo.drill.filterFields ignores the hub names when creating the model which allows the top clicks to be used in the results in both hubs. \\u00a0Additionally, the coveo.drill.userContextFields.0 and coveo.drill.userContextPrefixparameters force a specific context in the model so when we suggest top click we respect the context of the case which is product (field = c_context_product) in this example.<br><br><b>Example #5: \\u00a0</b><br>topClicks exportOffset: \\u201cP1D\\u201d, exportPeriod: \\u201cP3M\\u201d, refreshRate: \\u201cP1W\\u201d, searchEventFilter: \\u201coriginlevel1==\\u2018CustomerSearchPortal\\u2019\\u201d, matchAdvancedQuery: false, modifier: 500, maxResults: 10<br><br>Story:\\u00a0<br>Relevance tuning model is gathering 3 months of queries and click data. Model is refreshed each week. We only use the Customer Search Portal hub activity for this model. \\u00a0We will suggest 10 results instead of 5 results from the model.<br>\\u00a0</p>\"], \"originalhtmlcharset\": [1200], Model is refreshed each week. This model was built for a case creation page with the feature of long query(lq). We use two hubs (CaseCreate and Customer Search) to create this model. The customModelParameters setting coveo.drill.filterFields ignores the hub names when creating the model which allows the top clicks to be used in the results in both hubs. \\u00a0Additionally, the coveo.drill.userContextFields.0 and coveo.drill.userContextPrefixparameters force a specific context in the model so when we suggest top click we respect the context of the case which is product (field = c_context_product) in this example.<br><br><b>Example #5: \\u00a0</b><br>topClicks exportOffset: \\u201cP1D\\u201d, exportPeriod: \\u201cP3M\\u201d, refreshRate: \\u201cP1W\\u201d, searchEventFilter: \\u201coriginlevel1==\\u2018CustomerSearchPortal\\u2019\\u201d, matchAdvancedQuery: false, modifier: 500, maxResults: 10<br><br>Story:\\u00a0<br>Relevance tuning model is gathering 3 months of queries and click data. This is advanced settings \\n \\n * Not available via the UI. \\u00a0Needs to be added into the  QPL  manually.\\n \\n\\n Some options for the  Search API  can only be activated/changed\\u00a0through the QPL \\n \\n Example #1:\\u00a0 \\n topClicks exportOffset: \\\"P1D\\\", exportPeriod: \\\"P3M\\\", refreshRate: \\\"P1W\\\", searchEventFilter: \\\"originlevel1=='SearchPortal'\\\", matchAdvancedQuery: true, modifier: 1000 \\n \\n Story:\\u00a0 \\n Relevance tuning model is gathering 3 months of query and click data excluding today\\u2019s date. Model is refreshed each week. We only use the Search Portal hub activity for this model. \\u00a0The 5 best top clicks should be at the top with a score of 1000 \\n \\n \\n Example #2:\\u00a0 \\n topClicks exportOffset: \\\"P1D\\\", exportPeriod: \\\"P1W\\\", refreshRate: \\\"P1D\\\", searchEventFilter: \\\"originlevel1=='SearchPortal''\\\", modifier: 1000 \\n \\n Story:\\u00a0 \\n Relevance tuning model is gathering 1 week of queries and click data excluding today\\u2019s date. Model is refreshed each day. We only use the Search Portal hub activity for this model. \\u00a0The 5 best top clicks should be at the top with a score of 1000. \\n \\n Example #3:\\u00a0 \\n topClicks exportOffset: \\\"P1D\\\", searchEventFilter: \\\"(originlevel1=='External Search' OR originlevel1=='Internal Search') AND (documenturl=@'/coveo/')\\\", exportPeriod: \\\"P1M\\\", refreshRate: \\\"P1D\\\", modifier: 250, customModelParameters: [\\\"--conf\\\", \\\"coveo.drill.filterFields=\\\"] \\n \\n Story:\\u00a0 \\n Relevance tuning model is gathering 1 month of queries and click data excluding today\\u2019s date. Model is refreshed each day. We use activity from two hubs (External and Internal) to create this model. We only gather top clicks where the document URL contains /coveo/. The customModelParameters setting ignores the hub names when creating the model which allows the top clicks to be used in the results in both hubs.\\u00a0 \\n \\n Example #4:\\u00a0 \\n topClicks commonFilter: \\\"(originlevel1 IN [\\\\\\\"CaseCreate\\\\\\\",\\\\\\\"Customer_Search\\\\\\\"])\\\", searchEventFilter: \\\"(originlevel1 IN [\\\\\\\"CaseCreate\\\\\\\",\\\\\\\"Customer_Search\\\\\\\"])\\\", customEventFilter: \\\"(originlevel1 IN [\\\\\\\"CaseCreate\\\\\\\",\\\\\\\"Customer_Search\\\\\\\"])\\\", exportPeriod: \\\"P3M\\\", refreshRate: \\\"P1W\\\", modifier: 250, matchQuery: false, matchAdvancedQuery: true, useRefinedQuery: true, customModelParameters: [\\\"--conf\\\", \\\"coveo.drill.userContextFields.0=c_context_product\\\", \\\"--conf\\\",\\\"coveo.drill.userContextPrefix=badprefix\\\",\\\"--conf\\\", \\\"coveo.drill.filterFields=\\\" ] \\n \\n Story:\\u00a0 \\n Relevance tuning model is gathering 3 months of queries and clicks data. Model is refreshed each week. This model was built for a case creation page with the feature of long query(lq). We use two hubs (CaseCreate and Customer Search) to create this model. The customModelParameters setting coveo.drill.filterFields ignores the hub names when creating the model which allows the top clicks to be used in the results in both hubs. \\u00a0Additionally, the coveo.drill.userContextFields.0 and coveo.drill.userContextPrefixparameters force a specific context in the model so when we suggest top click we respect the context of the case which is product (field = c_context_product) in this example. \\n \\n Example #5: \\u00a0 \\n topClicks exportOffset: \\u201cP1D\\u201d, exportPeriod: \\u201cP3M\\u201d, refreshRate: \\u201cP1W\\u201d, searchEventFilter: \\u201coriginlevel1==\\u2018CustomerSearchPortal\\u2019\\u201d, matchAdvancedQuery: false, modifier: 500, maxResults: 10 \\n \\n Story:\\u00a0 \\n Relevance tuning model is gathering 3 months of queries and click data. Model is refreshed each week. Model is refreshed each week. This model was built for a case creation page with the feature of long query(lq). We use two hubs (CaseCreate and Customer Search) to create this model. The customModelParameters setting coveo.drill.filterFields ignores the hub names when creating the model which allows the top clicks to be used in the results in both hubs. \\u00a0Additionally, the coveo.drill.userContextFields.0 and coveo.drill.userContextPrefixparameters force a specific context in the model so when we suggest top click we respect the context of the case which is product (field = c_context_product) in this example.<br><br><b>Example #5: \\u00a0</b><br>topClicks exportOffset: \\u201cP1D\\u201d, exportPeriod: \\u201cP3M\\u201d, refreshRate: \\u201cP1W\\u201d, searchEventFilter: \\u201coriginlevel1==\\u2018CustomerSearchPortal\\u2019\\u201d, matchAdvancedQuery: false, modifier: 500, maxResults: 10<br><br>Story:\\u00a0<br>Relevance tuning model is gathering 3 months of queries and click data.       "sfdetailsc" : "<p>Below are Machine Learning Model Examples<br><br><b>Model types:</b><br>Topclicks:        Automatic Relevance Tuning (ART)<br>Recommendation:    Recommendations    <br>querySuggest:        Query Suggestions<br><br><b>Parameter information:</b><br>exportOffset*:    The duration you will exclude in the model from today’s date<br>exportPeriod:     The duration you will export in the model<br>refreshRate:       How often you will refresh the model<br>searchEventFilter:     All filters you want to use in the search event<br>clickEventFilter:     All filters you want to use in the click event<br>customEventFilter:    All filters you want to use in the custom event<br>Modifier:         The score/weight you give to ML suggestions<br>maxResults*:         If you want to show more than 5 suggestions<br>customModelParameters*:      Allow you to ignore some settings. This is advanced settings<br><br>* Not available via the UI.  Needs to be added into the <a href=\"https://developers.coveo.com/pages/releaseview.action?pageId=18350826\" target=\"_blank\">QPL</a> manually.</p>\n\n<p>Some options for the <a href=\"https://developers.coveo.com/display/public/SearchREST/REST+Search+API+Models\" target=\"_blank\">Search API</a> can only be activated/changed through the QPL<br><br><b>Example #1: </b><br>topClicks exportOffset: &quot;P1D&quot;, exportPeriod: &quot;P3M&quot;, refreshRate: &quot;P1W&quot;, searchEventFilter: &quot;originlevel1==&#39;SearchPortal&#39;&quot;, matchAdvancedQuery: true, modifier: 1000<br><br>Story: <br>Relevance tuning model is gathering 3 months of query and click data excluding today’s date. Model is refreshed each week. We only use the Search Portal hub activity for this model.  The 5 best top clicks should be at the top with a score of 1000<br><br><br><b>Example #2: </b><br>topClicks exportOffset: &quot;P1D&quot;, exportPeriod: &quot;P1W&quot;, refreshRate: &quot;P1D&quot;, searchEventFilter: &quot;originlevel1==&#39;SearchPortal&#39;&#39;&quot;, modifier: 1000<br><br>Story: <br>Relevance tuning model is gathering 1 week of queries and click data excluding today’s date. Model is refreshed each day. We only use the Search Portal hub activity for this model.  The 5 best top clicks should be at the top with a score of 1000.<br><br><b>Example #3: </b><br>topClicks exportOffset: &quot;P1D&quot;, searchEventFilter: &quot;(originlevel1==&#39;External Search&#39; OR originlevel1==&#39;Internal Search&#39;) AND (documenturl=@&#39;/coveo/&#39;)&quot;, exportPeriod: &quot;P1M&quot;, refreshRate: &quot;P1D&quot;, modifier: 250, customModelParameters: [&quot;--conf&quot;, &quot;coveo.drill.filterFields=&quot;]<br><br>Story: <br>Relevance tuning model is gathering 1 month of queries and click data excluding today’s date. Model is refreshed each day. We use activity from two hubs (External and Internal) to create this model. We only gather top clicks where the document URL contains /coveo/. The customModelParameters setting ignores the hub names when creating the model which allows the top clicks to be used in the results in both hubs. <br><br><b>Example #4: </b><br>topClicks commonFilter: &quot;(originlevel1 IN [\\&quot;CaseCreate\\&quot;,\\&quot;Customer_Search\\&quot;])&quot;, searchEventFilter: &quot;(originlevel1 IN [\\&quot;CaseCreate\\&quot;,\\&quot;Customer_Search\\&quot;])&quot;, customEventFilter: &quot;(originlevel1 IN [\\&quot;CaseCreate\\&quot;,\\&quot;Customer_Search\\&quot;])&quot;, exportPeriod: &quot;P3M&quot;, refreshRate: &quot;P1W&quot;, modifier: 250, matchQuery: false, matchAdvancedQuery: true, useRefinedQuery: true, customModelParameters: [&quot;--conf&quot;, &quot;coveo.drill.userContextFields.0=c_context_product&quot;, &quot;--conf&quot;,&quot;coveo.drill.userContextPrefix=badprefix&quot;,&quot;--conf&quot;, &quot;coveo.drill.filterFields=&quot; ]<br><br>Story: <br>Relevance tuning model is gathering 3 months of queries and clicks data. Model is refreshed each week. This model was built for a case creation page with the feature of long query(lq). We use two hubs (CaseCreate and Customer Search) to create this model. The customModelParameters setting coveo.drill.filterFields ignores the hub names when creating the model which allows the top clicks to be used in the results in both hubs.  Additionally, the coveo.drill.userContextFields.0 and coveo.drill.userContextPrefixparameters force a specific context in the model so when we suggest top click we respect the context of the case which is product (field = c_context_product) in this example.<br><br><b>Example #5:  </b><br>topClicks exportOffset: “P1D”, exportPeriod: “P3M”, refreshRate: “P1W”, searchEventFilter: “originlevel1==‘CustomerSearchPortal’”, matchAdvancedQuery: false, modifier: 500, maxResults: 10<br><br>Story: <br>Relevance tuning model is gathering 3 months of queries and click data. Model is refreshed each week. We only use the Customer Search Portal hub activity for this model.  We will suggest 10 results instead of 5 results from the model.<br> </p>",

\"kav_articlenumber\": [\"000002189\"], \"sfdetailsc\": [\"Here is some information about Visits and Click-through before we talk about creating a visit click-through metric card.\\n<h4><u><b>Visits:</b></u></h4>\\n\\n<ul><li>Someone that visit your site will get two cookies.</li><li>One cookie for the current visit and one permanent to calculate the unique user count.</li><li>A visit expires after 30 minutes of inactivity so if the user comes in the morning and in the afternoon, he will get two visits but will count as 1 unique user</li><li>Visits can be analysed and exported from the Visit browser</li></ul>\\n\\n<h4><u><b>Click-Through:</b></u></h4>\\nThere are two metrics for click-through.<br>1) The one that you see in the metrics selection called Click-through (%) or Clickthrough by query/query clickthrough<br><img alt=\\\"User-added image\\\" src=\\\"https://c.na61.content.force.com/servlet/rtaImage?eid=ka032000000HAEZ&amp;feoid=00N32000002jMQL&amp;refid=0EM32000000VO2e\\\"></img><br>2) The other one you see in a visit card called\\u00a0visit click-through (%).<br><img alt=\\\"User-added image\\\" src=\\\"https://c.na61.content.force.com/servlet/rtaImage?eid=ka032000000HAEZ&amp;feoid=00N32000002jMQL&amp;refid=0EM32000000VO2j\\\"></img>\\n<ul><li><b>Query Click-through</b> is based on each query. If one user does 4 queries and 2 of them generated a click, you will have 50% Query click-through</li><li><b>Visit Click-through</b> is based on the entire visit. That same user with 4 queries will have a visit click-through of 100% because he opened at least one document during his entire visit.\\u00a0</li></ul>\\n<br><b>Note</b>: Visit click-through is usually higher than query click-through<br><br>To create a visit click-through card:\\n<ul><li>Edit a dashboard</li><li>Add a Visit Card</li></ul>\\n\\u00a0 \\u00a0 \\u00a0 \\u00a0\\u00a0<img alt=\\\"User-added image\\\" height=\\\"105\\\" src=\\\"https://c.na61.content.force.com/servlet/rtaImage?eid=ka032000000HAEZ&amp;feoid=00N32000002jMQL&amp;refid=0EM32000000VO2o\\\" width=\\\"500\\\"></img>\\n<ul><li>Select your hub name if not already at the top of your dashboard. \\u00a0(i.e. origin level 1 = community)</li><li>Add the query is not empty filter so you are making sure a search was performed in the whole visit and you are not looking at visit with only page views\\u00a0</li><li>Select visit click-through in the drop list</li></ul>\\n<img alt=\\\"User-added image\\\" height=\\\"341\\\" src=\\\"https://c.na61.content.force.com/servlet/rtaImage?eid=ka032000000HAEZ&amp;feoid=00N32000002jMQL&amp;refid=0EM32000000VO2t\\\" width=\\\"500\\\"></img>\\n<ul><li>Save the dashboard</li></ul>\\n<br>Note: If you click on the title of this visit card, you won&#39;t see just the visits that contain\\u00a0only click. unique user count.</li><li>A visit expires after 30 minutes of inactivity so if the user comes in the morning and in the afternoon, he will get two visits but will count as 1 unique user</li><li>Visits can be analysed and exported from the Visit browser</li></ul>\\n\\n<h4><u><b>Click-Through:</b></u></h4>\\nThere are two metrics for click-through.<br>1) The one that you see in src=\\\"https://c.na61.content.force.com/servlet/rtaImage?eid=ka032000000HAEZ&amp;feoid=00N32000002jMQL&amp;refid=0EM32000000VO2e\\\"></img><br>2) The other one you see in a visit card query. If one user does 4 queries and 2 of them generated a click, you will have 50% Query click-through</li><li><b>Visit Click-through</b> is based on the entire visit. That same user with 4 queries will have a visit click-through of 100% because he opened at least one document during his entire visit.\\u00a0</li></ul>\\n<br><b>Note</b>: Visit click-through is usually higher than query click-through<br><br>To create a visit click-through card:\\n<ul><li>Edit a dashboard</li><li>Add a Visit Card</li></ul>\\n\\u00a0 \\u00a0 \\u00a0 \\u00a0\\u00a0<img alt=\\\"User-added image\\\" height=\\\"105\\\" src=\\\"https://c.na61.content.force.com/servlet/rtaImage?eid=ka032000000HAEZ&amp;feoid=00N32000002jMQL&amp;refid=0EM32000000VO2o\\\" width=\\\"500\\\"></img>\\n<ul><li>Select your hub name if not already at the top of your dashboard. \\u00a0(i.e. origin level 1 = community)</li><li>Add the query is not empty filter so you are making sure a search was performed in the whole visit and you are not looking at visit with only page views\\u00a0</li><li>Select visit click-through in the drop list</li></ul>\\n<img alt=\\\"User-added image\\\" height=\\\"341\\\" src=\\\"https://c.na61.content.force.com/servlet/rtaImage?eid=ka032000000HAEZ&amp;feoid=00N32000002jMQL&amp;refid=0EM32000000VO2t\\\" width=\\\"500\\\"></img>\\n<ul><li>Save the dashboard</li></ul>\\n<br>Note: If you click on the title of this visit card, you won&#39;t see just the visits that contain\\u00a0only click. (ART) (Coveo Machine Learning)</b></h1>\\nART is one of the features of Coveo machine learning. Click <a href=\\\"https://onlinehelp.coveo.com/en/cloud/coveo_machine_learning_features.htm#Automatic_Relevance_Tuning_(ART)_Feature\\\" target=\\\"_blank\\\">here</a>\\u00a0to learn more.\\u00a0ART currently supports Coveo for Salesforce - Communities Edition, not yet Coveo for Salesforce - Service Cloud Edition. When your agents also use Coveo for Salesforce, it is recommended to NOT activate ART on your agent hub by creating a filter to feed the model only with usage analytics data from your Community hub.\\n\\n<h1><b>What is Coveo Machine learning ?\\u00a0</b></h1>\\n<em>Coveo\\u2122 Machine Learning</em>\\u00a0(Coveo ML)\\u00a0is a cloud and analytics-based machine learning service that continually analyzes search behavior patterns to understand which results and content lead to the best outcomes, such as customer self-service success. In addition to intuitively enhancing search results so the best-performing content always rises to the top, Coveo ML automatically delivers the most relevant search results and proactive recommendations with minimal effort. Click <a href=\\\"https://onlinehelp.coveo.com/en/cloud/coveo_machine_learning.htm\\u00a0\\\" target=\\\"_blank\\\">here </a>to learn more.\\n\\n<h1><b>Evaluate if your environment is ready for ART ?\\u00a0</b></h1>\\nhttps://onlinehelp.coveo.com/en/cloud/evaluating_if_your_search_interface_produces_enough_data_for_art.htm\\n\\n<h1><b>Can I activate ART in my sandbox?</b></h1>\\nART learns from user behavior hence it needs high volume and user journeys with positive outcomes to learn from, which is why it is best to activate in your production environment. The recommended approach is perform an A/B test such that a part of your traffic goes through the ART pipeline and the rest through your regular pipeline. An out of the box dashboard will allow you to track progress on both pipelines.\\n\\n<h2><b>Step 1: Duplicate Pipeline</b></h2>\\nClick <a href=\\\"https://onlinehelp.coveo.com/en/cloud/managing_query_pipelines.htm#Duplicate\\\" target=\\\"_blank\\\">here </a>to learn detailed steps on creating your duplicate pipeline After you have created your duplicate pipeline leave the pipeline as is for now, <b>do not apply any conditions.\\u00a0</b>\\n\\n<h2>STEP 2: <b>Create\\u00a0your ART Model</b></h2>\\nThe Coveo\\u2122 Machine Learning (Coveo ML)\\u00a0features leverage usage analytics data by creating and training algorithmic models to predict and recommend which content is most helpful to users. Coveo ML is a service managed by Coveo that you can view like a &#39;scientist in a box&#39; that handles the model complexity. Click to learn more on <a href=\\\"https://onlinehelp.coveo.com/en/cloud/coveo_machine_learning_models.htm\\\" target=\\\"_blank\\\">Coveo Machine learning model</a><br><br>\\u00a0 \\u00a0 \\u00a0 \\u00a0<img alt=\\\"User-added image\\\" height=\\\"186\\\" src=\\\"https://c.na61.content.force.com/servlet/rtaImage?eid=ka032000000H8MM&amp;feoid=00N32000002jMQL&amp;refid=0EM32000000VNLO\\\" width=\\\"500\\\"></img><br><br>Here are the simple steps to create your ART Model\\n<ul><li>Open\\u00a0the pipeline that you duplicated</li><li>Select &quot;Reveal&quot;</li><li>Click <b>&quot;Add a Model&quot;</b></li><li>Select <b>Tune relevance </b>on the drop down to Select Model Type</li><li>Select a <b>frequency </b>and <b>data period.</b>\\u00a0If you are selecting a shorter data period you might want to choose a higher frequency as well.\\u00a0</li><li><b>Train on -</b> If you have a community, you would want the ART model to learn from your customer community and apply the learnings to your\\u00a0community. Learn about training and retraining <a href=\\\"https://onlinehelp.coveo.com/en/cloud/coveo_machine_learning_models.htm#Training\\\" target=\\\"_blank\\\">here</a>. There are multiple possibilities here, you can apply filters and learn only from a specific hub or a specific region.\\u00a0</li><li><b>Condition:</b> You need a condition if you have more than one\\u00a0audience in your pipeline. If for example only customers portal users go through pipeline you won\\u2019t need a condition but if you have case creation page + customer community, you will need to add a condition to mention the hub name where the model will be used. In the condition to be applied section apply the condition that selects the specific hub where you would like to activate ART.</li><li>The instructions to create or update the model are sent to the Coveo ML service. You will see the sign &quot;processing&quot; and once it is ready you will see the sign &quot;active&quot;. The ART model is active but remember no user is being sent to this pipeline yet. We will create the A/B test that will deliver the traffic to both pipeline based on the proportions selected.\\u00a0</li></ul>\\nClick <a href=\\\"https://onlinehelp.coveo.com/en/cloud/managing_machine_learning_automatic_relevance_tuning_in_a_query_pipeline.htm\\\" target=\\\"_blank\\\">here </a>to know detailed information on creating your ART model. [Check under topic <b>Manager Automatic Relevance Tuning</b>].\\n\\n<h2><br>STEP 3: Create\\u00a0<b>your A/B Test</b></h2>\\nHere are the steps to activate your A/B test. Click <a href=\\\"https://onlinehelp.coveo.com/en/cloud/managing_ab_tests.htm\\\" target=\\\"_blank\\\">here </a>to learn more on managing A/B tests.\\n\\n<ul><li>Under Search Optimization , select <b>A/B test</b></li></ul>\\n<b>\\u00a0 \\u00a0 \\u00a0 \\u00a0 \\u00a0\\u00a0<img alt=\\\"User-added image\\\" src=\\\"https://c.na61.content.force.com/servlet/rtaImage?eid=ka032000000H8MM&amp;feoid=00N32000002jMQL&amp;refid=0EM32000000VNLT\\\"></img></b>\\n\\n<ul><li>Click <b>Add Test </b>and\\u00a0Select your original pipeline in pipeline A and your duplicate pipeline where you have activated ART as pipeline B</li></ul>\\n<b>\\u00a0 \\u00a0 \\u00a0 \\u00a0 \\u00a0\\u00a0<img alt=\\\"User-added image\\\" src=\\\"https://c.na61.content.force.com/servlet/rtaImage?eid=ka032000000H8MM&amp;feoid=00N32000002jMQL&amp;refid=0EM32000000VNLY\\\"></img></b>\\n\\n<ul><li>By default the distribution of traffic is 50:50. You can change this setting, but you&#39;ll be able to see the difference that ART makes if you send equal traffic to both pipelines.\\u00a0</li></ul>\\n\\n<h2>STEP 4: Activate\\u00a0<b>your A/B Test</b></h2>\\n\\n<ul><li>After you&#39;ve created your A/B test you will land on the A/B test page where you see all the A/B tests you&#39;ve created so far.</li></ul>\\nFor Coveo Cloud V1 :\\n\\n<ul><li>Click the Actions icon (<img src=\\\"https://onlinehelp.coveo.com/en/cloud/Images/Icon-SourceActions.png\\\"></img>) next to the A/B test you want to activate and select\\u00a0Activate test.\\u00a0</li></ul>\\nFor Coveo Cloud V2:\\n\\n<ul><li>Click the row of the A/B test you want to activate\\u00a0</li><li>In the Action bar, click\\u00a0<b>More</b>, and then select\\u00a0Activate test</li></ul>\\nOnce your A/B test is active and your ART model is active, you will start to see user data come through both pipeline. Create the out of the box A/B test dashboard to track your progress. Here are some <a href=\\\"https://onlinehelp.coveo.com/en/cloud/ab_tests_best_practices.htm\\\" target=\\\"_blank\\\">A/B testing Best Practices</a> to learn from.\\u00a0<br>\\u00a0\"], \"originalhtmlcharset\": [1200], \"coveo_connector_hasbinarydata\": [false], \"kav_lastpublisheddate\": [1489631955], \"sfsystemmodstamp\": [1518176788], \"ka_attribute.type\": [\"Best_Practice__ka\"], \"sfdcproduct\": [\"Cloud Platform;Cloud Services;Coveo Enterprise Search;Salesforce;Usage Analytics\"], \"objecttypelabelplural\": [\"Best Practices\"], \"sftitle\": [\"Activate Automatic Relevance Tuning (Coveo machine learning) - You can change this setting, but you&#39;ll be able to see the difference that ART makes if you send equal traffic to both pipelines.\\u00a0</li></ul>\\n\\n<h2>STEP 4: Activate\\u00a0<b>your A/B Test</b></h2>\\n\\n<ul><li>After you&#39;ve created your A/B test you will land on the A/B test page where you see all the A/B tests you&#39;ve created so far.</li></ul>\\nFor Coveo Cloud V1 :\\n\\n<ul><li>Click the Actions icon (<img src=\\\"https://onlinehelp.coveo.com/en/cloud/Images/Icon-SourceActions.png\\\"></img>) next to the A/B test you want to activate and select\\u00a0Activate test.\\u00a0</li></ul>\\nFor Coveo Cloud V2:\\n\\n<ul><li>Click the row of the A/B test you want to activate\\u00a0</li><li>In the Action bar, click\\u00a0<b>More</b>, and then select\\u00a0Activate test</li></ul>\\nOnce your A/B test is active and your ART model is active, you will start to see user data come through both pipeline. (ART) (Coveo Machine Learning) \\nART is one of the features of Coveo machine learning. Click  here \\u00a0to learn more.\\u00a0ART currently supports Coveo for Salesforce - Communities Edition, not yet Coveo for Salesforce - Service Cloud Edition. When your agents also use Coveo for Salesforce, it is recommended to NOT activate ART on your agent hub by creating a filter to feed the model only with usage analytics data from your Community hub.\\n\\n What is Coveo Machine learning ?\\u00a0 \\n Coveo\\u2122 Machine Learning \\u00a0(Coveo ML)\\u00a0is a cloud and analytics-based machine learning service that continually analyzes search behavior patterns to understand which results and content lead to the best outcomes, such as customer self-service success. In addition to intuitively enhancing search results so the best-performing content always rises to the top, Coveo ML automatically delivers the most relevant search results and proactive recommendations with minimal effort. Click  here  to learn more.\\n\\n Evaluate if your environment is ready for ART ?\\u00a0 \\nhttps://onlinehelp.coveo.com/en/cloud/evaluating_if_your_search_interface_produces_enough_data_for_art.htm\\n\\n Can I activate ART in my sandbox? \\nART learns from user behavior hence it needs high volume and user journeys with positive outcomes to learn from, which is why it is best to activate in your production environment. The recommended approach is perform an A/B test such that a part of your traffic goes through the ART pipeline and the rest through your regular pipeline. An out of the box dashboard will allow you to track progress on both pipelines.\\n\\n Step 1: Duplicate Pipeline \\nClick  here  to learn detailed steps on creating your duplicate pipeline After you have created your duplicate pipeline leave the pipeline as is for now,  do not apply any conditions.\\u00a0 \\n\\n STEP 2:  Create\\u00a0your ART Model \\nThe Coveo\\u2122 Machine Learning (Coveo ML)\\u00a0features leverage usage analytics data by creating and training algorithmic models to predict and recommend which content is most helpful to users. Coveo ML is a service managed by Coveo that you can view like a 'scientist in a box' that handles the model complexity. Click to learn more on  Coveo Machine learning model \\n \\n \\u00a0 \\u00a0 \\u00a0 \\u00a0  \\n \\n Here are the simple steps to create your ART Model\\n Open\\u00a0the pipeline that you duplicated Select \\\"Reveal\\\" Click  \\\"Add a Model\\\" Select  Tune relevance  on the drop down to Select Model Type Select a  frequency  and  data period. \\u00a0If you are selecting a shorter data period you might want to choose a higher frequency as well.\\u00a0 Train on -  If you have a community, you would want the ART model to learn from your customer community and apply the learnings to your\\u00a0community. Learn about training and retraining  here . There are multiple possibilities here, you can apply filters and learn only from a specific hub or a specific region.\\u00a0 Condition:  You need a condition if you have more than one\\u00a0audience in your pipeline. If for example only customers portal users go through pipeline you won\\u2019t need a condition but if you have case creation page + customer community, you will need to add a condition to mention the hub name where the model will be used. In the condition to be applied section apply the condition that selects the specific hub where you would like to activate ART. The instructions to create or update the model are sent to the Coveo ML service. You will see the sign \\\"processing\\\" and once it is ready you will see the sign \\\"active\\\". The ART model is active but remember no user is being sent to this pipeline yet. We will create the A/B test that will deliver the traffic to both pipeline based on the proportions selected.\\u00a0 \\nClick  here  to know detailed information on creating your ART model. [Check under topic  Manager Automatic Relevance Tuning ].\\n\\n \\n STEP 3: Create\\u00a0 your A/B Test \\nHere are the steps to activate your A/B test. Click  here  to learn more on managing A/B tests.\\n\\n Under Search Optimization , select  A/B test \\n \\u00a0 \\u00a0 \\u00a0 \\u00a0 \\u00a0\\u00a0  \\n\\n Click  Add Test  and\\u00a0Select your original pipeline in pipeline A and your duplicate pipeline where you have activated ART as pipeline B \\n \\u00a0 \\u00a0 \\u00a0 \\u00a0 \\u00a0\\u00a0  \\n\\n By default the distribution of traffic is 50:50. You can change this setting, but you'll be able to see the difference that ART makes if you send equal traffic to both pipelines.\\u00a0 \\n\\n STEP 4: Activate\\u00a0 your A/B Test \\n\\n After you've created your A/B test you will land on the A/B test page where you see all the A/B tests you've created so far. \\nFor Coveo Cloud V1 :\\n\\n Click the Actions icon (  ) next to the A/B test you want to activate and select\\u00a0Activate test.\\u00a0 \\nFor Coveo Cloud V2:\\n\\n Click the row of the A/B test you want to activate\\u00a0 In the Action bar, click\\u00a0 More , and then select\\u00a0Activate test \\nOnce your A/B test is active and your ART model is active, you will start to see user data come through both pipeline. Create the out of the box A/B test dashboard to track your progress. Here are some  A/B testing Best Practices  to learn from.\\u00a0 \\n \\u00a0\"], \"sfarticlenumber\": [\"000001901\"], \"contenttype\": [\"binarydata\"], \"sfurlname\": [\"000001901\"], \"ka_id\": [\"kA032000000PNNaCAO\"], \"kav_datacategoryselections.datacategoryname\": [\"Coveo_Enterprise_Search;Cloud_Platform;Cloud_Services;Salesforce;Usage_Analytics;How_To\"], \"coveo_url\": [\"https://na61.salesforce.com/kA032000000PNNa\"], \"kav_urlname\": [\"000001901\"], \"kav_dc_expanded_product\": [\"All;All|Cloud Platform;All|Cloud Services;All|Coveo Enterprise Search;All|Salesforce;All|Usage Analytics\"], \"foldingcollection\": [\"d534d25308ee6545ad9603140a2ef1778f07cb52fa7c4b012db3ee6a60cc\"], \"kav_details__c\": [\"<h1><b>What is Automatic Relevance Tuning ? (ART) (Coveo Machine Learning)</b></h1>\\nART is one of the features of Coveo machine learning. Click <a href=\\\"https://onlinehelp.coveo.com/en/cloud/coveo_machine_learning_features.htm#Automatic_Relevance_Tuning_(ART)_Feature\\\" target=\\\"_blank\\\">here</a>\\u00a0to learn more.\\u00a0ART currently supports Coveo for Salesforce - Communities Edition, not yet Coveo for Salesforce - Service Cloud Edition. When your agents also use Coveo for Salesforce, it is recommended to NOT activate ART on your agent hub by creating a filter to feed the model only with usage analytics data from your Community hub.\\n\\n<h1><b>What is Coveo Machine learning ?\\u00a0</b></h1>\\n<em>Coveo\\u2122 Machine Learning</em>\\u00a0(Coveo ML)\\u00a0is a cloud and analytics-based machine learning service that continually analyzes search behavior patterns to understand which results and content lead to the best outcomes, such as customer self-service success. In addition to intuitively enhancing search results so the best-performing content always rises to the top, Coveo ML automatically delivers the most relevant search results and proactive recommendations with minimal effort. Click <a href=\\\"https://onlinehelp.coveo.com/en/cloud/coveo_machine_learning.htm\\u00a0\\\" target=\\\"_blank\\\">here </a>to learn more.\\n\\n<h1><b>Evaluate if your environment is ready for ART ?\\u00a0</b></h1>\\nhttps://onlinehelp.coveo.com/en/cloud/evaluating_if_your_search_interface_produces_enough_data_for_art.htm\\n\\n<h1><b>Can I activate ART in my sandbox?</b></h1>\\nART learns from user behavior hence it needs high volume and user journeys with positive outcomes to learn from, which is why it is best to activate in your production environment. The recommended approach is perform an A/B test such that a part of your traffic goes through the ART pipeline and the rest through your regular pipeline. An out of the box dashboard will allow you to track progress on both pipelines.\\n\\n<h2><b>Step 1: Duplicate Pipeline</b></h2>\\nClick <a href=\\\"https://onlinehelp.coveo.com/en/cloud/managing_query_pipelines.htm#Duplicate\\\" target=\\\"_blank\\\">here </a>to learn detailed steps on creating your duplicate pipeline After you have created your duplicate pipeline leave the pipeline as is for now, <b>do not apply any conditions.\\u00a0</b>\\n\\n<h2>STEP 2: <b>Create\\u00a0your ART Model</b></h2>\\nThe Coveo\\u2122 Machine Learning (Coveo ML)\\u00a0features leverage usage analytics data by creating and training algorithmic models to predict and recommend which content is most helpful to users. Coveo ML is a service managed by Coveo that you can view like a &#39;scientist in a box&#39; that handles the model complexity. Click to learn more on <a href=\\\"https://onlinehelp.coveo.com/en/cloud/coveo_machine_learning_models.htm\\\" target=\\\"_blank\\\">Coveo Machine learning model</a><br><br>\\u00a0 \\u00a0 \\u00a0 \\u00a0<img alt=\\\"User-added image\\\" height=\\\"186\\\" src=\\\"https://c.na61.content.force.com/servlet/rtaImage?eid=ka032000000H8MM&amp;feoid=00N32000002jMQL&amp;refid=0EM32000000VNLO\\\" width=\\\"500\\\"></img><br><br>Here are the simple steps to create your ART Model\\n<ul><li>Open\\u00a0the pipeline that you duplicated</li><li>Select &quot;Reveal&quot;</li><li>Click <b>&quot;Add a Model&quot;</b></li><li>Select <b>Tune relevance </b>on the drop down to Select Model Type</li><li>Select a <b>frequency </b>and <b>data period.</b>\\u00a0If you are selecting a shorter data period you might want to choose a higher frequency as well.\\u00a0</li><li><b>Train on -</b> If you have a community, you would want the ART model to learn from your customer community and apply the learnings to your\\u00a0community. Learn about training and retraining <a href=\\\"https://onlinehelp.coveo.com/en/cloud/coveo_machine_learning_models.htm#Training\\\" target=\\\"_blank\\\">here</a>. There are multiple possibilities here, you can apply filters and learn only from a specific hub or a specific region.\\u00a0</li><li><b>Condition:</b> You need a condition if you have more than one\\u00a0audience in your pipeline. If for example only customers portal users go through pipeline you won\\u2019t need a condition but if you have case creation page + customer community, you will need to add a condition to mention the hub name where the model will be used. In the condition to be applied section apply the condition that selects the specific hub where you would like to activate ART.</li><li>The instructions to create or update the model are sent to the Coveo ML service. You will see the sign &quot;processing&quot; and once it is ready you will see the sign &quot;active&quot;. The ART model is active but remember no user is being sent to this pipeline yet. We will create the A/B test that will deliver the traffic to both pipeline based on the proportions selected.\\u00a0</li></ul>\\nClick <a href=\\\"https://onlinehelp.coveo.com/en/cloud/managing_machine_learning_automatic_relevance_tuning_in_a_query_pipeline.htm\\\" target=\\\"_blank\\\">here </a>to know detailed information on creating your ART model. [Check under topic <b>Manager Automatic Relevance Tuning</b>].\\n\\n<h2><br>STEP 3: Create\\u00a0<b>your A/B Test</b></h2>\\nHere are the steps to activate your A/B test. Click <a href=\\\"https://onlinehelp.coveo.com/en/cloud/managing_ab_tests.htm\\\" target=\\\"_blank\\\">here </a>to learn more on managing A/B tests.\\n\\n<ul><li>Under Search Optimization , select <b>A/B test</b></li></ul>\\n<b>\\u00a0 \\u00a0 \\u00a0 \\u00a0 \\u00a0\\u00a0<img alt=\\\"User-added image\\\" src=\\\"https://c.na61.content.force.com/servlet/rtaImage?eid=ka032000000H8MM&amp;feoid=00N32000002jMQL&amp;refid=0EM32000000VNLT\\\"></img></b>\\n\\n<ul><li>Click <b>Add Test </b>and\\u00a0Select your original pipeline in pipeline A and your duplicate pipeline where you have activated ART as pipeline B</li></ul>\\n<b>\\u00a0 \\u00a0 \\u00a0 \\u00a0 \\u00a0\\u00a0<img alt=\\\"User-added image\\\" src=\\\"https://c.na61.content.force.com/servlet/rtaImage?eid=ka032000000H8MM&amp;feoid=00N32000002jMQL&amp;refid=0EM32000000VNLY\\\"></img></b>\\n\\n<ul><li>By default the distribution of traffic is 50:50. You can change this setting, but you&#39;ll be able to see the difference that ART makes if you send equal traffic to both pipelines.\\u00a0</li></ul>\\n\\n<h2>STEP 4: Activate\\u00a0<b>your A/B Test</b></h2>\\n\\n<ul><li>After you&#39;ve created your A/B test you will land on the A/B test page where you see all the A/B tests you&#39;ve created so far.</li></ul>\\nFor Coveo Cloud V1 :\\n\\n<ul><li>Click the Actions icon (<img src=\\\"https://onlinehelp.coveo.com/en/cloud/Images/Icon-SourceActions.png\\\"></img>) next to the A/B test you want to activate and select\\u00a0Activate test.\\u00a0</li></ul>\\nFor Coveo Cloud V2:\\n\\n<ul><li>Click the row of the A/B test you want to activate\\u00a0</li><li>In the Action bar, click\\u00a0<b>More</b>, and then select\\u00a0Activate test</li></ul>\\nOnce your A/B test is active and your ART model is active, you will start to see user data come through both pipeline. Create the out of the box A/B test dashboard to track your progress. Here are some <a href=\\\"https://onlinehelp.coveo.com/en/cloud/ab_tests_best_practices.htm\\\" target=\\\"_blank\\\">A/B testing Best Practices</a> to learn from.\\u00a0<br>\\u00a0\"],       "sfdetailsc" : "<h1><b>What is Automatic Relevance Tuning ? (ART) (Coveo Machine Learning)</b></h1>\nART is one of the features of Coveo machine learning. Click <a href=\"https://onlinehelp.coveo.com/en/cloud/coveo_machine_learning_features.htm#Automatic_Relevance_Tuning_(ART)_Feature\" target=\"_blank\">here</a> to learn more. ART currently supports Coveo for Salesforce - Communities Edition, not yet Coveo for Salesforce - Service Cloud Edition. When your agents also use Coveo for Salesforce, it is recommended to NOT activate ART on your agent hub by creating a filter to feed the model only with usage analytics data from your Community hub.\n\n<h1><b>What is Coveo Machine learning ? </b></h1>\n<em>Coveo™ Machine Learning</em> (Coveo ML) is a cloud and analytics-based machine learning service that continually analyzes search behavior patterns to understand which results and content lead to the best outcomes, such as customer self-service success. In addition to intuitively enhancing search results so the best-performing content always rises to the top, Coveo ML automatically delivers the most relevant search results and proactive recommendations with minimal effort. Click <a href=\"https://onlinehelp.coveo.com/en/cloud/coveo_machine_learning.htm \" target=\"_blank\">here </a>to learn more.\n\n<h1><b>Evaluate if your environment is ready for ART ? </b></h1>\nhttps://onlinehelp.coveo.com/en/cloud/evaluating_if_your_search_interface_produces_enough_data_for_art.htm\n\n<h1><b>Can I activate ART in my sandbox?</b></h1>\nART learns from user behavior hence it needs high volume and user journeys with positive outcomes to learn from, which is why it is best to activate in your production environment. The recommended approach is perform an A/B test such that a part of your traffic goes through the ART pipeline and the rest through your regular pipeline. An out of the box dashboard will allow you to track progress on both pipelines.\n\n<h2><b>Step 1: Duplicate Pipeline</b></h2>\nClick <a href=\"https://onlinehelp.coveo.com/en/cloud/managing_query_pipelines.htm#Duplicate\" target=\"_blank\">here </a>to learn detailed steps on creating your duplicate pipeline After you have created your duplicate pipeline leave the pipeline as is for now, <b>do not apply any conditions. </b>\n\n<h2>STEP 2: <b>Create your ART Model</b></h2>\nThe Coveo™ Machine Learning (Coveo ML) features leverage usage analytics data by creating and training algorithmic models to predict and recommend which content is most helpful to users. Coveo ML is a service managed by Coveo that you can view like a &#39;scientist in a box&#39; that handles the model complexity. Click to learn more on <a href=\"https://onlinehelp.coveo.com/en/cloud/coveo_machine_learning_models.htm\" target=\"_blank\">Coveo Machine learning model</a><br><br>       <img alt=\"User-added image\" height=\"186\" src=\"https://c.na61.content.force.com/servlet/rtaImage?eid=ka032000000H8MM&amp;feoid=00N32000002jMQL&amp;refid=0EM32000000VNLO\" width=\"500\"></img><br><br>Here are the simple steps to create your ART Model\n<ul><li>Open the pipeline that you duplicated</li><li>Select &quot;Reveal&quot;</li><li>Click <b>&quot;Add a Model&quot;</b></li><li>Select <b>Tune relevance </b>on the drop down to Select Model Type</li><li>Select a <b>frequency </b>and <b>data period.</b> If you are selecting a shorter data period you might want to choose a higher frequency as well. </li><li><b>Train on -</b> If you have a community, you would want the ART model to learn from your customer community and apply the learnings to your community. Learn about training and retraining <a href=\"https://onlinehelp.coveo.com/en/cloud/coveo_machine_learning_models.htm#Training\" target=\"_blank\">here</a>. There are multiple possibilities here, you can apply filters and learn only from a specific hub or a specific region. </li><li><b>Condition:</b> You need a condition if you have more than one audience in your pipeline. If for example only customers portal users go through pipeline you won’t need a condition but if you have case creation page + customer community, you will need to add a condition to mention the hub name where the model will be used. In the condition to be applied section apply the condition that selects the specific hub where you would like to activate ART.</li><li>The instructions to create or update the model are sent to the Coveo ML service. We will create the A/B test that will deliver the traffic to both pipeline based on the proportions selected. </li></ul>\nClick <a href=\"https://onlinehelp.coveo.com/en/cloud/managing_machine_learning_automatic_relevance_tuning_in_a_query_pipeline.htm\" target=\"_blank\">here </a>to know detailed information on creating your ART model. You can change this setting, but you&#39;ll be able to see the difference that ART makes if you send equal traffic to both pipelines. </li></ul>\n\n<h2>STEP 4: Activate <b>your A/B Test</b></h2>\n\n<ul><li>After you&#39;ve created your A/B test you will land on the A/B test page where you see all the A/B tests you&#39;ve created so far.</li></ul>\nFor Coveo Cloud V1 :\n\n<ul><li>Click the Actions icon (<img src=\"https://onlinehelp.coveo.com/en/cloud/Images/Icon-SourceActions.png\"></img>) next to the A/B test you want to activate and select Activate test. </li></ul>\nFor Coveo Cloud V2:\n\n<ul><li>Click the row of the A/B test you want to activate </li><li>In the Action bar, click <b>More</b>, and then select Activate test</li></ul>\nOnce your A/B test is active and your ART model is active, you will start to see user data come through both pipeline. Create the out of the box A/B test dashboard to track your progress. uri=\\\"https://na61.salesforce.com/kA00d0000009AiK\\\" /></parents>\"], \"sfisvisibleinprm\": [true], \"kav_title\": [\"What you need to check and do before Coveo disables TLS 1.0 on its Cloud Platform\"], \"sourcetype\": [\"Salesforce\"], \"kav_isvisibleincsp\": [true], \"hashtmlversion\": [true], \"kav_versionnumber\": [6], \"sfcreatedbyname\": [\"Jean-Fran\\u00e7ois Cadrin-Girard\"], \"objecttypelabel\": [\"Best Practice\"], \"kav_articlenumber\": [\"000003022\"], \"sfdetailsc\": [\"As per the PCI Security Standards Council decision to disable the TLS 1.0 protocol, Coveo will soon disable all TLS 1.0 connections to its Cloud Platform.<br><br>Both the v1 and v2 Platforms will be affected.<br><br>This article is intended to 1) help you identify if this change will affect you and 2) provide general plans of action to prevent any impacts.<br><br><b>Planned Date</b>: March 26, 2018<br>\\u00a0\\n<h1>What will NOT be affected when TLS 1.0 is disabled</h1>\\n\\n<ul><li>The Coveo for Salesforce package, including integration in Communities, as the connection goes through Salesforce\\u2019s infrastructure which is TLS-1.1+ compliant.</li><li>Any basic out-of-the-box Coveo Cloud Service: Indexing, Search, Usage Analytics, Machine Learning.</li><li>Any monitoring hook on our status pages, as these are hosted by a third-party.</li></ul>\\n\\n<h1><br>What WILL be affected when TLS 1.0 is disabled</h1>\\n\\n<table border=\\\"1\\\" style=\\\"\\\"><tbody><tr><td colspan=\\\"1\\\" rowspan=\\\"1\\\"><b>Scenario 1</b></td><td colspan=\\\"1\\\" rowspan=\\\"1\\\">Implementations of the Coveo JavaScript Search UI (or any other component based on the framework, such as recommendation panels) that connect to the Coveo Cloud Platform and are: 1) generally, <b>integrated in websites that run on web front-end servers</b> that have not been upgraded to TLS 1.1 or higher, or 2) specifically, any component of the application server that needs to connect to the Coveo Cloud .</td></tr><tr><td colspan=\\\"1\\\" rowspan=\\\"1\\\"><b>Scenario 2</b></td><td colspan=\\\"1\\\" rowspan=\\\"1\\\">Any <b>custom scripts, services or applications</b> that have been developed by yourself, a software implementer, or Coveo\\u2019s Professional Services, that connects to the Coveo Cloud Platform, and that are running on servers that have not been upgraded to TLS 1.1 or higher.</td></tr><tr><td colspan=\\\"1\\\" rowspan=\\\"1\\\"><b>Scenario 3</b></td><td colspan=\\\"1\\\" rowspan=\\\"1\\\">On-premise <b>Coveo Enterprise Search installations that use hybrid configurations</b> connecting to the Coveo Cloud Platform Search and/or Usage Analytics API(s) while running on servers that have not been upgraded to TLS 1.1 or higher.\\u00a0</td></tr><tr><td colspan=\\\"1\\\" rowspan=\\\"1\\\"><b>Scenario 4</b></td><td colspan=\\\"1\\\" rowspan=\\\"1\\\"><b>Coveo for Sitecore 3.0 February 2015 (3.0.955) to January 2016 (3.0.1226) without the additional TLS 1.2 package</b>. This scenario may include the use of Coveo Cloud V1 analytics with an on-premises Coveo for Sitecore setup.</td></tr></tbody></table>\\n\\n<h1><br>What needs to be done before TLS 1.0 is disabled</h1>\\n<b>NB</b>: It\\u2019s also important to consider any intermediary firewall, proxy, gateway, etc, in your infrastructure and located between the Coveo Cloud Platform and any of the servers described in each scenario. We recommend reviewing with your network team if need be.\\n\\n<table border=\\\"1\\\" style=\\\"\\\"><tbody><tr><td colspan=\\\"1\\\" rowspan=\\\"1\\\"><b>Scenario 1</b></td><td colspan=\\\"1\\\" rowspan=\\\"1\\\">Update the web front-end server\\u2019s TLS protocol to 1.1 or higher.</td></tr><tr><td colspan=\\\"1\\\" rowspan=\\\"1\\\"><b>Scenario 2</b></td><td colspan=\\\"1\\\" rowspan=\\\"1\\\">Update the script/service/application server\\u2019s TLS protocol to 1.1 or higher.</td></tr><tr><td colspan=\\\"1\\\" rowspan=\\\"1\\\"><b>Scenario 3</b></td><td colspan=\\\"1\\\" rowspan=\\\"1\\\">Update the Coveo Enterprise Search server\\u2019s TLS protocol to 1.1 or higher. \\u00a0</td></tr><tr><td colspan=\\\"1\\\" rowspan=\\\"1\\\"><b>Scenario 4</b></td><td colspan=\\\"1\\\" rowspan=\\\"1\\\">Follow the Coveo community article instructions to install the package and enable TLS 1.2 support\\u00a0</td></tr></tbody></table>\\n\\n<h2>\\u00a0</h2>\\n\\n<h3>References</h3>\\n\\n<p dir=\\\"ltr\\\"><b id=\\\"docs-internal-guid-d52e2cb0-4c58-9df5-1028-c9985e19a6f1\\\"><a id=\\\"docs-internal-guid-d52e2cb0-4c58-9df5-1028-c9985e19a6f1\\\"><a href=\\\"https://support.microsoft.com/en-ca/help/3140245/update-to-enable-tls-1-1-and-tls-1-2-as-a-default-secure-protocols-in\\\" target=\\\"_blank\\\">Update to enable TLS 1.1 and TLS 1.2 as a default secure protocols in WinHTTP in Windows</a></b></p>\\n\\n<p dir=\\\"ltr\\\"><b id=\\\"docs-internal-guid-d52e2cb0-4c58-9df5-1028-c9985e19a6f1\\\"><a href=\\\"https://developers.coveo.com/pages/releaseview.action?pageId=34898464\\\" target=\\\"_blank\\\">Coveo for Sitecore 4 SSL/TLS Support</a></b></p>\\n\\n<p dir=\\\"ltr\\\"><b [true], \"kav_details__c__html_stripped\": [\"As per the PCI Security Standards Council decision to disable the TLS 1.0 protocol, Coveo will soon disable all TLS 1.0 connections to its Cloud Platform. \\n \\n Both the v1 and v2 Platforms will be affected. \\n \\n This article is intended to 1) help you identify if this change will affect you and 2) provide general plans of action to prevent any impacts. \\n \\n Planned Date : March 26, 2018 \\n \\u00a0\\n What will NOT be affected when TLS 1.0 is disabled \\n\\n The Coveo for Salesforce package, including integration in Communities, as the connection goes through Salesforce\\u2019s infrastructure which is TLS-1.1+ compliant. Any basic out-of-the-box Coveo Cloud Service: Indexing, Search, Usage Analytics, Machine Learning. Any monitoring hook on our status pages, as these are hosted by a third-party. \\n\\n \\n What WILL be affected when TLS 1.0 is disabled \\n\\n Scenario 1 Implementations of the Coveo JavaScript Search UI (or any other component based on the framework, such as recommendation panels) that connect to the Coveo Cloud Platform and are: 1) generally,  integrated in websites that run on web front-end servers  that have not been upgraded to TLS 1.1 or higher, or 2) specifically, any component of the application server that needs to connect to the Coveo Cloud . Scenario 2 Any  custom scripts, services or applications  that have been developed by yourself, a software implementer, or Coveo\\u2019s Professional Services, that connects to the Coveo Cloud Platform, and that are running on servers that have not been upgraded to TLS 1.1 or higher. Scenario 3 On-premise  Coveo Enterprise Search installations that use hybrid configurations  connecting to the Coveo Cloud Platform Search and/or Usage Analytics API(s) while running on servers that have not been upgraded to TLS 1.1 or higher.\\u00a0 Scenario 4 Coveo for Sitecore 3.0 February 2015 (3.0.955) to January 2016 (3.0.1226) without the additional TLS 1.2 package . This scenario may include the use of Coveo Cloud V1 analytics with an on-premises Coveo for Sitecore setup. \\n\\n \\n What needs to be done before TLS 1.0 is disabled \\n NB : It\\u2019s also important to consider any intermediary firewall, proxy, gateway, etc, in your infrastructure and located between the Coveo Cloud Platform and any of the servers described in each scenario. We recommend reviewing with your network team if need be.\\n\\n Scenario 1 Update the web front-end server\\u2019s TLS protocol to 1.1 or higher. Scenario 2 Update the script/service/application server\\u2019s TLS protocol to 1.1 or higher. Scenario 3 Update the Coveo Enterprise Search server\\u2019s TLS protocol to 1.1 or higher. \\u00a0 Scenario 4 Follow the Coveo community article instructions to install the package and enable TLS 1.2 support\\u00a0 \\n\\n \\u00a0 \\n\\n References \\n\\n TLS/SSL Settings on Windows\\n \\n\\n Update to enable TLS 1.1 and TLS 1.2 as a default secure protocols in WinHTTP in Windows\\n \\n\\n Coveo for Sitecore 4 SSL/TLS Support\\n \\n\\n Coveo for Sitecore 3 SSL/TLS Support \\n \\n Coveo disabling TLS 1.0\\n \\n\\n \\u00a0\\n \\n \\n \\u00a0\"], \"sfarticlenumber\": [\"000003022\"], #BBC5CC;border-top: 1px solid #BBC5CC;color: #296896;padding: 10px;width: 15%;\\\">           Details         </div>       </div>       <div style=\\\"margin-left: 35px;margin-top: 10px;font-size: 1em;\\\">As per the PCI Security Standards Council decision to disable the TLS 1.0 protocol, Coveo will soon disable all TLS 1.0 connections to its Cloud Platform.<br><br>Both the v1 and v2 Platforms will be affected.<br><br>This article is intended to 1) help you identify if this change will affect you and 2) provide general plans of action to prevent any impacts.<br><br><b>Planned Date</b>: March 26, 2018<br>\\u00a0\\n<h1>What will NOT be affected when TLS 1.0 is disabled</h1>\\n\\n<ul><li>The Coveo for Salesforce package, including integration in Communities, as the connection goes through Salesforce\\u2019s infrastructure which is TLS-1.1+ compliant.</li><li>Any basic out-of-the-box Coveo Cloud Service: Indexing, Search, Usage Analytics, Machine Learning.</li><li>Any monitoring hook on our status pages, as these are hosted by a third-party.</li></ul>\\n\\n<h1><br>What WILL be affected when TLS 1.0 is disabled</h1>\\n\\n<table border=\\\"1\\\" style=\\\"\\\"><tbody><tr><td colspan=\\\"1\\\" rowspan=\\\"1\\\"><b>Scenario 1</b></td><td colspan=\\\"1\\\" rowspan=\\\"1\\\">Implementations of the Coveo JavaScript Search UI (or any other component based on the framework, such as recommendation panels) that connect to the Coveo Cloud Platform and are: 1) generally, <b>integrated in websites that run on web front-end servers</b> that have not been upgraded to TLS 1.1 or higher, or 2) specifically, any component of the application server that needs to connect to the Coveo Cloud .</td></tr><tr><td colspan=\\\"1\\\" rowspan=\\\"1\\\"><b>Scenario 2</b></td><td colspan=\\\"1\\\" rowspan=\\\"1\\\">Any <b>custom scripts, services or applications</b> that have been developed by yourself, a software implementer, or Coveo\\u2019s Professional Services, that connects to the Coveo Cloud Platform, and that are running on servers that have not been upgraded to TLS 1.1 or higher.</td></tr><tr><td colspan=\\\"1\\\" rowspan=\\\"1\\\"><b>Scenario 3</b></td><td colspan=\\\"1\\\" rowspan=\\\"1\\\">On-premise <b>Coveo Enterprise Search installations that use hybrid configurations</b> connecting to the Coveo Cloud Platform Search and/or Usage Analytics API(s) while running on servers that have not been upgraded to TLS 1.1 or higher.\\u00a0</td></tr><tr><td colspan=\\\"1\\\" rowspan=\\\"1\\\"><b>Scenario 4</b></td><td colspan=\\\"1\\\" rowspan=\\\"1\\\"><b>Coveo for Sitecore 3.0 February 2015 (3.0.955) to January 2016 (3.0.1226) without the additional TLS 1.2 package</b>. This scenario may include the use of Coveo Cloud V1 analytics with an on-premises Coveo for Sitecore setup.</td></tr></tbody></table>\\n\\n<h1><br>What needs to be done before TLS 1.0 is disabled</h1>\\n<b>NB</b>: It\\u2019s also important to consider any intermediary firewall, proxy, gateway, etc, in your infrastructure and located between the Coveo Cloud Platform and any of the servers described in each scenario. We recommend reviewing with your network team if need be.\\n\\n<table border=\\\"1\\\" style=\\\"\\\"><tbody><tr><td colspan=\\\"1\\\" rowspan=\\\"1\\\"><b>Scenario 1</b></td><td colspan=\\\"1\\\" support\\u00a0</td></tr></tbody></table>\\n\\n<h2>\\u00a0</h2>\\n\\n<h3>References</h3>\\n\\n<p dir=\\\"ltr\\\"><b id=\\\"docs-internal-guid-d52e2cb0-4c58-9df5-1028-c9985e19a6f1\\\"><a       "sfcurrencyisocode" : "USD",
      "sfbestpracticekavid" : "ka00d0000009kxyAAA",
      "sfkbid" : "kA00d0000009AiKCAU",
      "sfdetailsc" : "As per the PCI Security Standards Council decision to disable the TLS 1.0 protocol, Coveo will soon disable all TLS 1.0 connections to its Cloud Platform.<br><br>Both the v1 and v2 Platforms will be affected.<br><br>This article is intended to 1) help you identify if this change will affect you and 2) provide general plans of action to prevent any impacts.<br><br><b>Planned Date</b>: March 26, 2018<br> \n<h1>What will NOT be affected when TLS 1.0 is disabled</h1>\n\n<ul><li>The Coveo for Salesforce package, including integration in Communities, as the connection goes through Salesforce’s infrastructure which is TLS-1.1+ compliant.</li><li>Any basic out-of-the-box Coveo Cloud Service: Indexing, Search, Usage Analytics, Machine Learning.</li><li>Any monitoring hook on our status pages, as these are hosted by a third-party.</li></ul>\n\n<h1><br>What WILL be affected when TLS 1.0 is disabled</h1>\n\n<table border=\"1\" style=\"\"><tbody><tr><td colspan=\"1\" rowspan=\"1\"><b>Scenario 1</b></td><td colspan=\"1\" rowspan=\"1\">Implementations of the Coveo JavaScript Search UI (or any other component based on the framework, such as recommendation panels) that connect to the Coveo Cloud Platform and are: 1) generally, <b>integrated in websites that run on web front-end servers</b> that have not been upgraded to TLS 1.1 or higher, or 2) specifically, any component of the application server that needs to connect to the Coveo Cloud .</td></tr><tr><td colspan=\"1\" rowspan=\"1\"><b>Scenario 2</b></td><td colspan=\"1\" rowspan=\"1\">Any <b>custom scripts, services or applications</b> that have been developed by yourself, a software implementer, or Coveo’s Professional Services, that connects to the Coveo Cloud Platform, and that are running on servers that have not been upgraded to TLS 1.1 or higher.</td></tr><tr><td colspan=\"1\" rowspan=\"1\"><b>Scenario 3</b></td><td colspan=\"1\" rowspan=\"1\">On-premise <b>Coveo Enterprise Search installations that use hybrid configurations</b> connecting to the Coveo Cloud Platform Search and/or Usage Analytics API(s) while running on servers that have not been upgraded to TLS 1.1 or higher. </td></tr><tr><td colspan=\"1\" rowspan=\"1\"><b>Scenario 4</b></td><td colspan=\"1\" rowspan=\"1\"><b>Coveo for Sitecore 3.0 February 2015 (3.0.955) to January 2016 (3.0.1226) without the additional TLS 1.2 package</b>. This scenario may include the use of Coveo Cloud V1 analytics with an on-premises Coveo for Sitecore setup.</td></tr></tbody></table>\n\n<h1><br>What needs to be done before TLS 1.0 is disabled</h1>\n<b>NB</b>: It’s also important to consider any intermediary firewall, proxy, gateway, etc, in your infrastructure and located between the Coveo Cloud Platform and any of the servers described in each scenario. We recommend reviewing with your network team if need be.\n\n<table border=\"1\" style=\"\"><tbody><tr><td colspan=\"1\" rowspan=\"1\"><b>Scenario 1</b></td><td colspan=\"1\" rowspan=\"1\">Update the web front-end server’s TLS protocol to 1.1 or higher.</td></tr><tr><td colspan=\"1\" rowspan=\"1\"><b>Scenario 2</b></td><td colspan=\"1\" rowspan=\"1\">Update the script/service/application server’s TLS protocol to 1.1 or higher.</td></tr><tr><td colspan=\"1\" rowspan=\"1\"><b>Scenario 3</b></td><td colspan=\"1\" rowspan=\"1\">Update the Coveo Enterprise Search server’s TLS protocol to 1.1 or higher.  </td></tr><tr><td colspan=\"1\" rowspan=\"1\"><b>Scenario 4</b></td><td colspan=\"1\" rowspan=\"1\">Follow the Coveo community article instructions to install the package and enable TLS 1.2 support </td></tr></tbody></table>\n\n<h2> </h2>\n\n<h3>References</h3>\n\n<p dir=\"ltr\"><b id=\"docs-internal-guid-d52e2cb0-4c58-9df5-1028-c9985e19a6f1\"><a href=\"https://technet.microsoft.com/en-us/library/dn786418(v=ws.11).aspx\" target=\"_blank\">TLS/SSL Settings on Windows</a></b></p>\n\n<p dir=\"ltr\"><b id=\"docs-internal-guid-d52e2cb0-4c58-9df5-1028-c9985e19a6f1\"><a href=\"https://support.microsoft.com/en-ca/help/3140245/update-to-enable-tls-1-1-and-tls-1-2-as-a-default-secure-protocols-in\" target=\"_blank\">Update to enable TLS 1.1 and TLS 1.2 as a default secure protocols in WinHTTP in Windows</a></b></p>\n\n<p dir=\"ltr\"><b id=\"docs-internal-guid-d52e2cb0-4c58-9df5-1028-c9985e19a6f1\"><a href=\"https://developers.coveo.com/pages/releaseview.action?pageId=34898464\" target=\"_blank\">Coveo for Sitecore 4 SSL/TLS Support</a></b></p>\n\n<p dir=\"ltr\"><b id=\"docs-internal-guid-d52e2cb0-4c58-9df5-1028-c9985e19a6f1\"><a href=\"https://developers.coveo.com/pages/releaseview.action?pageId=34243186\" target=\"_blank\">Coveo for Sitecore 3 SSL/TLS Support</a></b><br><br><b><a href=\"https://support.coveo.com/s/article/2321\" target=\"_blank\">Coveo disabling TLS 1.0</a></b></p>\n\n<p       "sfdcarticletype" : "How To/Question",
      "sfresolutionc" : "<u><b>Section 1 - On your Search Page</b></u><br><br>The firs thing to check is to make sure your Search Page is correctly configure and is sending data to Coveo Cloud Analytics. Indeed, if none or incomplete data is sent to the Coveo Cloud Analytics, the report will never display the correct results. <br><br>1 - Using a Developer tool such as Chrome, look at the code of your search page and ensure that you have a node div class=&quot;CoveoAnalytics&quot; (example bellow)\n<pre class=\"ckeditor_codeblock\">\n&lt;div class=&quot;CoveoAnalytics&quot; \ndata-user=&quot;domain\\user&quot; \ndata-endpoint=&quot;https://usageanalytics.coveo.com&quot; \ndata-token=&quot;yourToken&quot; \ndata-search-hub=&quot;yourHub&quot; \ndata-send-to-cloud=&quot;True&quot;&gt; \n&lt;/div&gt;</pre>\n2 - Using a Developer tool such as Chrome, perform a query on your search page. Then, look in the Network activity for an event such as:\n\n<pre class=\"ckeditor_codeblock\">\nusageanalytics.coveo.com/rest/v14/analytics</pre>\nMake sure the Status Code for that request is 200 OK.<br><br>3 - From the Network activity event identifies in step 2, check the <b>Query String Parameter</b> of the request.\n\n<pre class=\"ckeditor_codeblock\">\nsearchEvents:[\n\t{\n\t&quot;actionCause&quot;:&quot;searchboxSubmit&quot;,\n\t&quot;actionType&quot;:&quot;search box&quot;,\n\t&quot;username&quot;:&quot;extranet\\\\Anonymous&quot;,\n\t&quot;anonymous&quot;:false,\n\t&quot;device&quot;:&quot;Chrome&quot;,\n\t&quot;mobile&quot;:false,\n\t&quot;language&quot;:&quot;en&quot;,\n\t&quot;originLevel1&quot;:&quot;myWebsite&quot;,\n\t&quot;originLevel2&quot;:&quot;customOrigin2&quot;,\n\t&quot;customData&quot;:{\n\t\t&quot;JSUIVersion&quot;:&quot;0.9.1287.55;0.0.0.0&quot;,\n\t\t&quot;SiteDefinition&quot;:&quot;MyCustomParameterNamedSiteDefinition&quot;\t\n\t},\n\t&quot;userAgent&quot;:&quot;Mozilla/5.0 (Windows NT 6.3; WOW64) AppleWebKit/537.36 (KHTML, like Gecko) Chrome/50.0.2661.102 Safari/537.36&quot;,\n\t&quot;contextual&quot;:false,\n\t&quot;originLevel3&quot;:&quot;customOrigin3&quot;,\n\t&quot;queryPipeline&quot;:&quot;default&quot;,\n\t&quot;queryText&quot;:&quot;myQuery&quot;,\n\t&quot;advancedQuery&quot;:&quot;@syssource==(\\&quot;MySource\\&quot;)&quot;,\n\t&quot;didYouMean&quot;:true,\n\t&quot;numberOfResults&quot;:2,\n\t&quot;responseTime&quot;:141,\n\t&quot;pageNumber&quot;:0,\n\t&quot;resultsPerPage&quot;:10,\n\t&quot;searchQueryUid&quot;:&quot;90f386d7-8951-2b5e-091c-df675c2dcaf9&quot;\n\t}\n]</pre>\nThe goal of this is to identify any relevant information about the Data (used by <b>Named Filters</b> and <b>Dimensions</b>) that is sent to the Coveo Analytics such as:\n\n<ul><li>Value of originLevel1, originLevel2, originLevel3</li><li>Value of username</li><li>Any customData (This section is empty be default, only you can add content in it)</li><li>Etc. </li></ul>\n4 - Use this tool to ensure that your Coveo Analytic token is still valid:<br>https://cloudplatform.coveo.com/docs/#!/tokens/getTokenInformation<br><br><u><b>Section 2 - On your Analytic Dashboard or Report</b></u><br><br>1 - On your Coveo Cloud <b>Analtyic Console</b> ­­­­&gt;&gt; <b>Analytics</b> &gt;&gt; <b>Reports</b> &gt;&gt; <b>Your Report,</b> determine what are the <b>Named Filters</b> and the <b>Dimensions</b> that you will be using for your report:<br><br><img alt=\"User-added image\" height=\"526\" src=\"https://c.na61.content.force.com/servlet/rtaImage?eid=ka1320000008W6t&amp;feoid=00N32000002zy1J&amp;refid=0EM320000004hke\" width=\"500\"></img><br><br>2 - If you are using Named Filter, check in<b> Analytics</b> ­­&gt;&gt; <b>Named Filter </b>to determine on what the filters are based:<br><img alt=\"User-added image\" height=\"126\" src=\"https://c.na61.content.force.com/servlet/rtaImage?eid=ka1320000008W6t&amp;feoid=00N32000002zy1J&amp;refid=0EM320000004hko\" width=\"500\"></img><br>The goal here is to determine on what default or custom Dimensions each named filters is based on.<br>Also, it tells you what are the specific values that a Dimension much match in order to be included in the filter. <br><br>3 - The next step is to check the Dimensions on which these Named Filters are based on in <b>Analytics</b> ­­&gt;&gt; <b>Dimensions</b>:<br><img alt=\"User-added image\" height=\"105\" src=\"https://c.na61.content.force.com/servlet/rtaImage?eid=ka1320000008W6t&amp;feoid=00N32000002zy1J&amp;refid=0EM320000004hlS\" width=\"500\"></img><br><br>The goal of this step is to determine:<br>&gt;&gt; What are the APIname related to each of your dimensions<br>&gt;&gt; Are you able to see those dimensions in the <b>searchEvents</b> that is sent by your search page (see Section 1, step 3)<br><br><br><br><br><br><br><br><br><br> ",

Page</b></u><br><br>The firs thing to check is to make sure your Search Page is correctly configure and is sending data to Coveo Cloud Analytics. Indeed, if none or incomplete data is sent to the Coveo Cloud Analytics, the report will never display the correct results.\\u00a0<br><br>1 - Using a Developer tool such as Chrome, look at the code of your search page and ensure that you have a node\\u00a0div class=&quot;CoveoAnalytics&quot; (example bellow)\\n<pre class=\\\"ckeditor_codeblock\\\">\\n&lt;div class=&quot;CoveoAnalytics&quot; \\ndata-user=&quot;domain\\\\user&quot; \\ndata-endpoint=&quot;https://usageanalytics.coveo.com&quot; \\ndata-token=&quot;yourToken&quot; \\ndata-search-hub=&quot;yourHub&quot; \\ndata-send-to-cloud=&quot;True&quot;&gt; \\n&lt;/div&gt;</pre>\\n2 - Using a Developer tool such as Chrome, perform a query on your search page. Then, look in the Network activity for an event such as:\\n\\n<pre class=\\\"ckeditor_codeblock\\\">\\nusageanalytics.coveo.com/rest/v14/analytics</pre>\\nMake sure the Status Code for that request is 200 OK.<br><br>3 - From the Network activity event identifies in step 2, check the <b>Query String Parameter</b> of the request.\\n\\n<pre it)</li><li>Etc.\\u00a0</li></ul>\\n4 - Use this tool to ensure that your Coveo Analytic token is still will be using for your report:<br><br><img alt=\\\"User-added image\\\" height=\\\"526\\\" href=\\\"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Natural_language_processing\\\" target=\\\"_blank\\\">Natural Language Processing </a>(NLP) will extract terms based on linguistic rules and/or frequency of words alone.</p>\\n\\n<p>Coveo\\u2019s approach is different, \\u00a0in addition to traditional NLP methods, it leverages the vocabulary used by past users when they searched for content. This provides a more accurate picture of what is relevant to users in this context.\\u00a0</p>\\n\\n<p>Usually, a query contains an average of 4 words, which is relatively simple to manage. \\u00a0However, new use cases have shown demand for using paragraph size text as input queries, such as using the description of a support case to help agents find a solution more efficiently. \\u00a0But, the query management algorithm is not designed to deal with that many words. \\u00a0Therefore, Coveo ML now provides the new <a href=\\\"https://developers.coveo.com/display/public/SalesforceV2/Activating+Machine+Learning+Intelligent+Term+Detection+%28ITD%29+in+Salesforce\\\" target=\\\"_blank\\\">Intelligent Term Detection</a>\\u00a0(ITD) algorithm, which uses machine learning to determine which words, from the whole text, are the most relevant. \\u00a0</p>\\n\\n<p>To do so, the ITD algorithm uses the set of past events (search, click, pageviews), from the search interface. \\u00a0It selects which queries were successful and generated a positive outcome (clicks). It finds a correlation between theses successful queries and the words contained in the long queries. It aims to find the 5 most relevant terms and rank each of them with weighted value. \\u00a0These 5 terms, are called the \\u201c<i>Refined Query</i>\\u201d. \\u00a0It is the Refined Query that is used by the search algorithm to find the most relevant document from the Coveo Index.</p> \\t\\t\\t</div> \\t\\t</div>  \\t</body> </html>\"], \"sfpublishstatus\": [\"Online\"], \"sfcreatedbyid\": [\"00560000003q7JgAAI\"], \"sfknowledgearticleid\": [\"kA30d0000004STjCAM\"], \"kav_islatestversion\": [true], \"kav_knowledgearticleid\": [\"kA30d0000004STjCAM\"], \"kav_answer__c__html_stripped\": [\"A typical  Natural Language Processing  (NLP) will extract terms based on linguistic rules and/or frequency of words alone.\\n \\n\\n Coveo\\u2019s approach is different, \\u00a0in addition to traditional NLP methods, it leverages the vocabulary used by past users when they searched for content. This provides a more accurate picture of what is relevant to users in this context.\\u00a0\\n \\n\\n Usually, a query contains an average of 4 words, which is relatively simple to manage. \\u00a0However, new use cases have shown demand for using paragraph size text as input queries, such as using the description of a support case to help agents find a solution more efficiently. \\u00a0But, the query management algorithm is not designed to deal with that many words. \\u00a0Therefore, Coveo ML now provides the new  Intelligent Term Detection \\u00a0(ITD) algorithm, which uses machine learning to determine which words, from the whole text, are the most relevant. \\u00a0\\n \\n\\n To do so, the ITD algorithm uses the set of past events (search, click, pageviews), from the search interface. \\u00a0It selects which queries were successful and generated a positive outcome (clicks). It finds a correlation between theses successful queries and the words contained in the long queries. It aims to find the 5 most relevant terms and rank each of them with weighted value. \\u00a0These 5 terms, are called the \\u201c Refined Query \\u201d. \\u00a0It is the Refined Query that is used by the search algorithm to find the most relevant document from the Coveo Index.\\n\"], \"kav_datacategoryselections.attribute.type\": [\"FAQ__DataCategorySelection;FAQ__DataCategorySelection\"],
