From a technology/information perspective the definition is more refined: A measure of how closely a given object (file, web page, database record, etc.) matches a user\\u2019s search for information<br><br><b>What is relevancy testing\\u00a0</b><br>It is an exercise where a small group of users test your site (authenticated or public) for relevancy of search results. On a high level it constitutes users performing queries and providing feedback on the quality of the results generated.<br><br><b>How is relevancy testing different from relevancy tuning?</b><br>Relevancy testing is usually a one time activity performed before Go live, relevancy tuning is an on-going activity based on where you are on the relevancy maturity model. Read more here: http://blog.coveo.com/coveo-relevance-maturity-model/\\u00a0<br><br><b>Why perform relevancy testing ?</b><br>It lets you gather feedback and overall impressions from real users around relevancy of search results. Relevancy testing is different from functional testing as it focuses more around the usefulness and relevance of information presented to your end users. The end goal is to understand how easy or how difficult it is for users to find the information they&#39;re looking for and what can you do to improve that experience before the product goes out the door.\\u00a0<br><br><b>When to perform relevancy testing ?</b><br>This activity should be conducted before the site is generally available to all audience i.e. before your Go Live.<br><br><b>How many users to include for relevancy testing ?</b>\\n<ul><li>We recommend you to conduct relevancy testing with a smaller group of users. Less than 10 users with a varied experience is recommended</li><li>Users should ideally come from different departments and experience levels so you get feedback from different perspectives.\\u00a0</li></ul>\\n<b>How much time is needed for relevancy testing ?</b><br>We recommend maximum two iterations of testing before Go Live. In the first iteration you collect user feedback, make modifications based on that feedback and perform the second iteration. Set expectations for the users that conducted the relevancy tuning on what they should expect to see a change in and items that will be modified after go live.\\u00a0<br><br><b>What should be tested ?\\u00a0</b><br>You should have separate test cases for each use case; meaning if you are going live with an internal community, your end users will be employees, if you are going live with a agent insight panel, your end users will be agents. The vocabulary for search used by different users will differ based on the use case. For example - your customers might use different keywords (example: I can\\u2019t print) while searching for an article whereas an agent\\u2019s keywords might be more focused (example: Can\\u2019t output documents, LPT1 troubleshooting).<br><br>Here is a sample script that can guide on what you should be testing.\\u00a0<br>\\u00a0\\n<table border=\\\"1\\\" style=\\\"width: 500px;\\\"><caption><u>Sample Script - If so, which ones did they apply</li><li>Are they seeing outdated content?</li></ul>\\n<b>What to do with the feedback from relevancy testing?</b><br>The feedback that you collect from relevancy testing can be of various types\\n<ol><li>Users can find all information perfectly\\u00a0</li><li>Users can find information but it is lower in the list of results - You can boost results or set articles as featured result.\\u00a0</li><li>Sometimes content changes might be required, such as changing article title or summaries to make content more relevant</li></ol>\\n<br>\\u00a0\"], \"originalhtmlcharset\": [1200], \"coveo_connector_hasbinarydata\": [false], \"kav_lastpublisheddate\": [1488215371], \"sfsystemmodstamp\": [1516362333], \"ka_attribute.type\": [\"Best_Practice__ka\"], \"sfdcproduct\": [\"All\"], \"objecttypelabelplural\": [\"Best Practices\"], \"sftitle\": [\"Best Practices - From a technology/information perspective the definition is more refined: A measure of how closely a given object (file, web page, database record, etc.) matches a user\\u2019s search for information \\n \\n What is relevancy testing\\u00a0 \\n It is an exercise where a small group of users test your site (authenticated or public) for relevancy of search results. On a high level it constitutes users performing queries and providing feedback on the quality of the results generated. \\n \\n How is relevancy testing different from relevancy tuning? \\n Relevancy testing is usually a one time activity performed before Go live, relevancy tuning is an on-going activity based on where you are on the relevancy maturity model. Read more here: http://blog.coveo.com/coveo-relevance-maturity-model/\\u00a0 \\n \\n Why perform relevancy testing ? \\n It lets you gather feedback and overall impressions from real users around relevancy of search results. Relevancy testing is different from functional testing as it focuses more around the usefulness and relevance of information presented to your end users. The end goal is to understand how easy or how difficult it is for users to find the information they're looking for and what can you do to improve that experience before the product goes out the door.\\u00a0 \\n \\n When to perform relevancy testing ? \\n This activity should be conducted before the site is generally available to all audience i.e. before your Go Live. \\n \\n How many users to include for relevancy testing ? \\n We recommend you to conduct relevancy testing with a smaller group of users. Less than 10 users with a varied experience is recommended Users should ideally come from different departments and experience levels so you get feedback from different perspectives.\\u00a0 \\n How much time is needed for relevancy testing ? \\n We recommend maximum two iterations of testing before Go Live. In the first iteration you collect user feedback, make modifications based on that feedback and perform the second iteration. Set expectations for the users that conducted the relevancy tuning on what they should expect to see a change in and items that will be modified after go live.\\u00a0 \\n \\n What should be tested ?\\u00a0 \\n You should have separate test cases for each use case; meaning if you are going live with an internal community, your end users will be employees, if you are going live with a agent insight panel, your end users will be agents. The vocabulary for search used by different users will differ based on the use case. For example - your customers might use different keywords (example: I can\\u2019t print) while searching for an article whereas an agent\\u2019s keywords might be more focused (example: Can\\u2019t output documents, LPT1 troubleshooting). \\n \\n Here is a sample script that can guide on what you should be testing.\\u00a0 \\n \\u00a0\\n Sample Script - Relevancy Testing Test Scenario Topics Expressions Expected Results Rank Comments 1 Password Password Reset Article 30507: How to reset customer password 2 I found the article in the Knowledgebase Tab, does not appear in first 5 results in the ALL tab. \\u00a0 \\u00a0 Forgot Password \\u00a0 \\u00a0 \\u00a0 2 \\u00a0 \\u00a0 \\u00a0 \\u00a0 \\u00a0 \\n Tips for Comments Column: \\n\\n Specifically ask users around the ranking of the expected results, do they see in the first 5 results? Do they not see it at all? Do they see too much content of a particular source that is overshadowing the\\u00a0 Did they see better results after switching Tabs or selecting filters? If so, which ones did they apply Are they seeing outdated content? \\n What to do with the feedback from relevancy testing? \\n The feedback that you collect from relevancy testing can be of various types\\n Users can find all information perfectly\\u00a0 Users can find information but it is lower in the list of results - You can boost results or set articles as featured result.\\u00a0 Sometimes content changes might be required, such as changing article title or summaries to make content more relevant \\n \\n \\u00a0\"], \"sfarticlenumber\": [\"000002083\"], \"contenttype\": [\"binarydata\"], \"sfurlname\": [\"000002083\"], \"ka_id\": [\"kA032000000PO0hCAG\"], \"kav_datacategoryselections.datacategoryname\": [\"All;How_To\"], \"coveo_url\": [\"https://na61.salesforce.com/kA032000000PO0h\"], \"kav_urlname\": [\"000002083\"], \"kav_dc_expanded_product\": [\"All;All|.NET Search Interface;All|Cloud Platform;All|Cloud Services;All|Community;All|Coveo Enterprise Search;All|Javascript Search Interface;All|Other;All|REST Search API;All|Salesforce;All|Sitecore;All|Usage Analytics\"], \"foldingcollection\": [\"36899f4ebcca81e7a239e7ca32e89e1694aeee9d8055b9a1582a46264b72\"], \"kav_details__c\": [\"<b>What is relevancy?</b><br>The general definition of relevance is: The quality or state of being closely connected or appropriate. From a technology/information perspective the definition is more refined: A measure of how closely a given object (file, web page, database record, etc.) matches a user\\u2019s search for information<br><br><b>What is relevancy testing\\u00a0</b><br>It is an exercise where a small group of users test your site (authenticated or public) for relevancy of search results. On a high level it constitutes users performing queries and providing feedback on the quality of the results generated.<br><br><b>How is relevancy testing different from relevancy tuning?</b><br>Relevancy testing is usually a one time activity performed before Go live, relevancy tuning is an on-going activity based on where you are on the relevancy maturity model. Read more here: http://blog.coveo.com/coveo-relevance-maturity-model/\\u00a0<br><br><b>Why perform relevancy testing ?</b><br>It lets you gather feedback and overall impressions from real users around relevancy of search results. Relevancy testing is different from functional testing as it focuses more around the usefulness and relevance of information presented to your end users. The end goal is to understand how easy or how difficult it is for users to find the information they&#39;re looking for and what can you do to improve that experience before the product goes out the door.\\u00a0<br><br><b>When to perform relevancy testing ?</b><br>This activity should be conducted before the site is generally available to all audience i.e. before your Go Live.<br><br><b>How many users to include for relevancy testing ?</b>\\n<ul><li>We recommend you to conduct relevancy testing with a smaller group of users. Less than 10 users with a varied experience is recommended</li><li>Users should ideally come from different departments and experience levels so you get feedback from different perspectives.\\u00a0</li></ul>\\n<b>How much time is needed for relevancy testing ?</b><br>We recommend maximum two iterations of testing before Go Live. In the first iteration you collect user feedback, make modifications based on that feedback and perform the second iteration. Set expectations for the users that conducted the relevancy tuning on what they should expect to see a change in and items that will be modified after go live.\\u00a0<br><br><b>What should be tested ?\\u00a0</b><br>You should have separate test cases for each use case; meaning if you are going live with an internal community, your end users will be employees, if you are going live with a agent insight panel, your end users will be agents. The vocabulary for search used by different users will differ based on the use case. For example - your customers might use different keywords (example: I can\\u2019t print) while searching for an article whereas an agent\\u2019s keywords might be more focused (example: Can\\u2019t output documents, LPT1 troubleshooting).<br><br>Here is a sample script that can guide on what you should be testing.\\u00a0<br>\\u00a0\\n<table border=\\\"1\\\" style=\\\"width: 500px;\\\"><caption><u>Sample Script - Relevancy Testing</u></caption><thead><tr><th colspan=\\\"1\\\" rowspan=\\\"1\\\">Test Scenario</th><th colspan=\\\"1\\\" rowspan=\\\"1\\\">Topics</th><th colspan=\\\"1\\\" rowspan=\\\"1\\\">Expressions</th><th colspan=\\\"1\\\" rowspan=\\\"1\\\">Expected Results</th><th colspan=\\\"1\\\" rowspan=\\\"1\\\">Rank</th><th colspan=\\\"1\\\" rowspan=\\\"1\\\">Comments</th></tr></thead><tbody><tr><td colspan=\\\"1\\\" rowspan=\\\"1\\\">1</td><td colspan=\\\"1\\\" rowspan=\\\"1\\\">Password</td><td colspan=\\\"1\\\" rowspan=\\\"1\\\">Password Reset</td><td colspan=\\\"1\\\" rowspan=\\\"1\\\">Article 30507: How to reset customer password</td><td colspan=\\\"1\\\" rowspan=\\\"1\\\">2</td><td colspan=\\\"1\\\" rowspan=\\\"1\\\">I found the article in the Knowledgebase Tab, does not appear in first 5 results in the ALL tab.</td></tr><tr><td colspan=\\\"1\\\" rowspan=\\\"1\\\">\\u00a0</td><td colspan=\\\"1\\\" rowspan=\\\"1\\\">\\u00a0</td><td colspan=\\\"1\\\" rowspan=\\\"1\\\">Forgot Password</td><td colspan=\\\"1\\\" rowspan=\\\"1\\\">\\u00a0</td><td colspan=\\\"1\\\" rowspan=\\\"1\\\">\\u00a0</td><td colspan=\\\"1\\\" rowspan=\\\"1\\\">\\u00a0</td></tr><tr><td colspan=\\\"1\\\" rowspan=\\\"1\\\">2</td><td colspan=\\\"1\\\" rowspan=\\\"1\\\">\\u00a0</td><td colspan=\\\"1\\\" rowspan=\\\"1\\\">\\u00a0</td><td colspan=\\\"1\\\" rowspan=\\\"1\\\">\\u00a0</td><td colspan=\\\"1\\\" rowspan=\\\"1\\\">\\u00a0</td><td colspan=\\\"1\\\" rowspan=\\\"1\\\">\\u00a0</td></tr></tbody></table>\\n<b>Tips for Comments Column:</b>\\n\\n<ul><li>Specifically ask users around the ranking of the expected results, do they see in the first 5 results? Do they not see it at all?</li><li>Do they see too much content of a particular source that is overshadowing the\\u00a0</li><li>Did they see better results after switching Tabs or selecting filters? If so, which ones did they apply</li><li>Are they seeing outdated content?</li></ul>\\n<b>What to do with the feedback from relevancy testing?</b><br>The feedback that you collect from relevancy testing can be of various types\\n<ol><li>Users can find all information perfectly\\u00a0</li><li>Users can find information but it is lower in the list of results - You can boost results or set articles as featured result.\\u00a0</li><li>Sometimes content changes might be required, such as changing article title or summaries to make content more relevant</li></ol>\\n<br>\\u00a0\"],       "sfdetailsc" : "<b>What is relevancy?</b><br>The general definition of relevance is: The quality or state of being closely connected or appropriate. From a technology/information perspective the definition is more refined: A measure of how closely a given object (file, web page, database record, etc.) matches a user’s search for information<br><br><b>What is relevancy testing </b><br>It is an exercise where a small group of users test your site (authenticated or public) for relevancy of search results. On a high level it constitutes users performing queries and providing feedback on the quality of the results generated.<br><br><b>How is relevancy testing different from relevancy tuning?</b><br>Relevancy testing is usually a one time activity performed before Go live, relevancy tuning is an on-going activity based on where you are on the relevancy maturity model. Read more here: http://blog.coveo.com/coveo-relevance-maturity-model/ <br><br><b>Why perform relevancy testing ?</b><br>It lets you gather feedback and overall impressions from real users around relevancy of search results. Relevancy testing is different from functional testing as it focuses more around the usefulness and relevance of information presented to your end users. The end goal is to understand how easy or how difficult it is for users to find the information they&#39;re looking for and what can you do to improve that experience before the product goes out the door. <br><br><b>When to perform relevancy testing ?</b><br>This activity should be conducted before the site is generally available to all audience i.e. before your Go Live.<br><br><b>How many users to include for relevancy testing ?</b>\n<ul><li>We recommend you to conduct relevancy testing with a smaller group of users. Less than 10 users with a varied experience is recommended</li><li>Users should ideally come from different departments and experience levels so you get feedback from different perspectives. </li></ul>\n<b>How much time is needed for relevancy testing ?</b><br>We recommend maximum two iterations of testing before Go Live. In the first iteration you collect user feedback, make modifications based on that feedback and perform the second iteration. Set expectations for the users that conducted the relevancy tuning on what they should expect to see a change in and items that will be modified after go live. <br><br><b>What should be tested ? </b><br>You should have separate test cases for each use case; meaning if you are going live with an internal community, your end users will be employees, if you are going live with a agent insight panel, your end users will be agents. The vocabulary for search used by different users will differ based on the use case. For example - your customers might use different keywords (example: I can’t print) while searching for an article whereas an agent’s keywords might be more focused (example: Can’t output documents, LPT1 troubleshooting).<br><br>Here is a sample script that can guide on what you should be testing. <br> \n<table border=\"1\" style=\"width: 500px;\"><caption><u>Sample Script - Relevancy Testing</u></caption><thead><tr><th colspan=\"1\" rowspan=\"1\">Test Scenario</th><th colspan=\"1\" rowspan=\"1\">Topics</th><th colspan=\"1\" rowspan=\"1\">Expressions</th><th colspan=\"1\" rowspan=\"1\">Expected Results</th><th colspan=\"1\" rowspan=\"1\">Rank</th><th colspan=\"1\" rowspan=\"1\">Comments</th></tr></thead><tbody><tr><td colspan=\"1\" rowspan=\"1\">1</td><td colspan=\"1\" rowspan=\"1\">Password</td><td colspan=\"1\" rowspan=\"1\">Password Reset</td><td colspan=\"1\" rowspan=\"1\">Article 30507: How to reset customer password</td><td colspan=\"1\" rowspan=\"1\">2</td><td colspan=\"1\" rowspan=\"1\">I found the article in the Knowledgebase Tab, does not appear in first 5 results in the ALL tab.</td></tr><tr><td colspan=\"1\" rowspan=\"1\"> </td><td colspan=\"1\" rowspan=\"1\"> </td><td colspan=\"1\" rowspan=\"1\">Forgot Password</td><td colspan=\"1\" rowspan=\"1\"> </td><td colspan=\"1\" rowspan=\"1\"> </td><td colspan=\"1\" rowspan=\"1\"> </td></tr><tr><td colspan=\"1\" rowspan=\"1\">2</td><td colspan=\"1\" rowspan=\"1\"> </td><td colspan=\"1\" rowspan=\"1\"> </td><td colspan=\"1\" rowspan=\"1\"> </td><td colspan=\"1\" rowspan=\"1\"> </td><td colspan=\"1\" rowspan=\"1\"> </td></tr></tbody></table>\n<b>Tips for Comments Column:</b>\n\n<ul><li>Specifically ask users around the ranking of the expected results, do they see in the first 5 results? Do they not see it at all?</li><li>Do they see too much content of a particular source that is overshadowing the </li><li>Did they see better results after switching Tabs or selecting filters? If so, which ones did they apply</li><li>Are they seeing outdated content?</li></ul>\n<b>What to do with the feedback from relevancy testing?</b><br>The feedback that you collect from relevancy testing can be of various types\n<ol><li>Users can find all information perfectly </li><li>Users can find information but it is lower in the list of results - You can boost results or set articles as featured result. </li><li>Sometimes content changes might be required, such as changing article title or summaries to make content more relevant</li></ol>\n<br> ",

Coveo provides multiple mechanisms to optimize your search results like post conversion scripts that are used to manipulate the document properties and ways to boost or demote content, create synonyms and the works by the help of <a href=\\\"https://onlinehelp.coveo.com/en/cloud/creating_and_managing_query_pipelines.htm\\\" target=\\\"_blank\\\">pipeline maintenance.</a>\\u00a0<br><br><b>Clear your Clutter</b><br>It is important that you either archive or delete files that serve no purpose to your audience. Any outdated or duplicate content will only increase the noise in your search results and serve no additional value.\\u00a0<br><br><b>Naming Convention</b><br>A file name is what identifies a document/file and is one of the most important search attributes.\\n<ul><li>Use meaningful names, names that are used by your end-users and can be recognized easily.</li><li>Use spaces between words, words that are placed together without a separation are treated as a single string</li><li>Have keywords in your document titles so they can be spotted easily</li></ul>\\n<b>Metadata</b><br>Metadata is all the important information about a file or a document like the document title, author, created date, published date, tags etc that can be used to improve the relevancy of your search results.\\u00a0\\n<ul><li>Keywords in file names, pages, and descriptions increase relevance.</li><li>Adding tags to your document that describe their purpose is another useful way of categorizing content.\\u00a0</li></ul>\\n<b>Close the Loop</b><br>Coveo&#39;s rich analytics will help you identify gaps in your content by clearly showing when end-users don&#39;t find what they&#39;re looking for or don&#39;t click on results or log a case even after clicking on multiple documents. This is good feedback for you to provide to your content team but you should always aim towards closing the loop with direct user feedback. You should establish a clear and easy process where end-users can provide feedback on content. If they can&#39;t find what they&#39;re looking for or if they find old/outdated content they should be able to communicate that in some way. This keeps your content fresh and relevant.\\u00a0<br><br><br><br><br><br><br><br><br><br>\\u00a0\"], \"originalhtmlcharset\": [1200], \"coveo_connector_hasbinarydata\": [false], \"kav_lastpublisheddate\": [1480647387], \"sfsystemmodstamp\": [1516362333], \"ka_attribute.type\": [\"Best_Practice__ka\"], \"objecttypelabelplural\": [\"Best Practices\"], \"sftitle\": [\"Content Management Best Practices\"], \"kav_owner.id\": [\"00532000005Jm2DAAS\"], \"kav_details__c\": [\"One of the very important aspects of providing a great user experience is providing your audience with great content. Coveo provides multiple mechanisms to optimize your search results like post conversion scripts that are used to manipulate the document properties and ways to boost or demote content, create synonyms and the works by the help of <a href=\\\"https://onlinehelp.coveo.com/en/cloud/creating_and_managing_query_pipelines.htm\\\" target=\\\"_blank\\\">pipeline maintenance.</a>\\u00a0<br><br><b>Clear your Clutter</b><br>It is important that you either archive or delete files that serve no purpose to your audience. Any outdated or duplicate content will only increase the noise in your search results and serve no additional value.\\u00a0<br><br><b>Naming Convention</b><br>A file name is what identifies a document/file and is one of the most important search attributes.\\n<ul><li>Use meaningful names, names that are used by your end-users and can be recognized easily.</li><li>Use spaces between words, words that are placed together without a separation are treated as a single string</li><li>Have keywords in your document titles so they can be spotted easily</li></ul>\\n<b>Metadata</b><br>Metadata is all the important information about a file or a document like the document title, author, created date, published date, tags etc that can be used to improve the relevancy of your search results.\\u00a0\\n<ul><li>Keywords in file names, pages, and descriptions increase relevance.</li><li>Adding tags to your document that describe their purpose is another useful way of categorizing content.\\u00a0</li></ul>\\n<b>Close the Loop</b><br>Coveo&#39;s rich analytics will help you identify gaps in your content by clearly showing when end-users don&#39;t find what they&#39;re looking for or don&#39;t click on results or log a case even after clicking on multiple documents. This is good feedback for you to provide to your content team but you should always aim towards closing the loop with direct user feedback. You should establish a clear and easy process where end-users can provide feedback on content. If they can&#39;t find what they&#39;re looking for or if they find old/outdated content they should be able to communicate that in some way. Coveo provides multiple mechanisms to optimize your search results like post conversion scripts that are used to manipulate the document properties and ways to boost or demote content, create synonyms and the works by the help of  pipeline maintenance. \\u00a0 \\n \\n Clear your Clutter \\n It is important that you either archive or delete files that serve no purpose to your audience. Any outdated or duplicate content will only increase the noise in your search results and serve no additional value.\\u00a0 \\n \\n Naming Convention \\n A file name is what identifies a document/file and is one of the most important search attributes.\\n Use meaningful names, names that are used by your end-users and can be recognized easily. Use spaces between words, words that are placed together without a separation are treated as a single string Have keywords in your document titles so they can be spotted easily \\n Metadata \\n Metadata is all the important information about a file or a document like the document title, author, created date, published date, tags etc that can be used to improve the relevancy of your search results.\\u00a0\\n Keywords in file names, pages, and descriptions increase relevance. Adding tags to your document that describe their purpose is another useful way of categorizing content.\\u00a0 \\n Close the Loop \\n Coveo's rich analytics will help you identify gaps in your content by clearly showing when end-users don't find what they're looking for or don't click on results or log a case even after clicking on multiple documents. This is good feedback for you to provide to your content team but you should always aim towards closing the loop with direct user feedback. You should establish a clear and easy process where end-users can provide feedback on content. If they can't find what they're looking for or if they find old/outdated content they should be able to communicate that in some way.         <tr>           <td style=\\\"margin-left: 35px;margin-top: 10px;font-size: 1em;font-weight: 600;\\\">Product</td><td></td>         </tr>       </table>       <br/>       <div style=\\\"font-size: 1.5em;font-weight: 600;Padding-top: 30px;border-bottom: 1px solid #BBC5CC;\\\">         <div style=\\\"border-left: 1px solid #BBC5CC;border-top: 1px solid #BBC5CC;color: #296896;padding: 10px;width: 15%;\\\">           Details         </div>       </div>       <div style=\\\"margin-left: 35px;margin-top: 10px;font-size: 1em;\\\">One of the very important aspects of providing a great user experience is providing your audience with great content. Coveo provides multiple mechanisms to optimize your search results like post conversion scripts that are used to manipulate the document properties and ways to boost or demote content, create synonyms and the works by the help of <a href=\\\"https://onlinehelp.coveo.com/en/cloud/creating_and_managing_query_pipelines.htm\\\" target=\\\"_blank\\\">pipeline maintenance.</a>\\u00a0<br><br><b>Clear your Clutter</b><br>It is important that you either archive or delete files that serve no purpose to your audience. Any outdated or duplicate content will only increase the noise in your search results and serve no additional value.\\u00a0<br><br><b>Naming Convention</b><br>A file name is what identifies a document/file and is one of the most important search attributes.\\n<ul><li>Use meaningful names, names that are used by your end-users and can be recognized easily.</li><li>Use spaces between words, words that are placed together without a separation are treated as a single string</li><li>Have keywords in your document titles so they can be spotted easily</li></ul>\\n<b>Metadata</b><br>Metadata is all the important information about a file or a document like the document title, author, created date, published date, tags etc that can be used to improve the relevancy of your search results.\\u00a0\\n<ul><li>Keywords in file names, pages, and descriptions increase relevance.</li><li>Adding tags to your document that describe their purpose is another useful way of categorizing content.\\u00a0</li></ul>\\n<b>Close the Loop</b><br>Coveo&#39;s rich analytics will help you identify gaps in your content by clearly showing when end-users don&#39;t find what they&#39;re looking for or don&#39;t click on results or log a case even after clicking on multiple documents. This is good feedback for you to provide to your content team but you should always aim towards closing the loop with direct user feedback. You should establish a clear and easy process where end-users can provide feedback on content. If they can&#39;t find what they&#39;re looking for or if they find old/outdated content they should be able to communicate that in some way. This keeps your content fresh and relevant.\\u00a0<br><br><br><br><br><br><br><br><br><br>\\u00a0</div>     </div>   </body> </html>\"], \"sfpublishstatus\": [\"Online\"], \"sfcreatedbyid\":       "sfdetailsc" : "One of the very important aspects of providing a great user experience is providing your audience with great content. Coveo provides multiple mechanisms to optimize your search results like post conversion scripts that are used to manipulate the document properties and ways to boost or demote content, create synonyms and the works by the help of <a href=\"https://onlinehelp.coveo.com/en/cloud/creating_and_managing_query_pipelines.htm\" target=\"_blank\">pipeline maintenance.</a> <br><br><b>Clear your Clutter</b><br>It is important that you either archive or delete files that serve no purpose to your audience. Any outdated or duplicate content will only increase the noise in your search results and serve no additional value. <br><br><b>Naming Convention</b><br>A file name is what identifies a document/file and is one of the most important search attributes.\n<ul><li>Use meaningful names, names that are used by your end-users and can be recognized easily.</li><li>Use spaces between words, words that are placed together without a separation are treated as a single string</li><li>Have keywords in your document titles so they can be spotted easily</li></ul>\n<b>Metadata</b><br>Metadata is all the important information about a file or a document like the document title, author, created date, published date, tags etc that can be used to improve the relevancy of your search results. \n<ul><li>Keywords in file names, pages, and descriptions increase relevance.</li><li>Adding tags to your document that describe their purpose is another useful way of categorizing content. </li></ul>\n<b>Close the Loop</b><br>Coveo&#39;s rich analytics will help you identify gaps in your content by clearly showing when end-users don&#39;t find what they&#39;re looking for or don&#39;t click on results or log a case even after clicking on multiple documents. This is good feedback for you to provide to your content team but you should always aim towards closing the loop with direct user feedback. You should establish a clear and easy process where end-users can provide feedback on content. If they can&#39;t find what they&#39;re looking for or if they find old/outdated content they should be able to communicate that in some way. This keeps your content fresh and relevant. <br><br><br><br><br><br><br><br><br><br> ",

thesaurus:<br><img alt=\\\"User-added image\\\" src=\\\"https://c.na61.content.force.com/servlet/rtaImage?eid=ka032000000HAHd&amp;feoid=00N32000002jMQL&amp;refid=0EM32000000VNrH\\\"></img><br>Note: guide and User Technical manual<br><br><u><b>Expand Any:</b></u> is searching all synonyms in your content as soon as one word is part of user expression.<br>Do not forget if an article meets more than one synonym of your rule, the weight will add up\\u00a0for each word we find in the article<br><br>Popular Use Case:<br>Your content has different qualifiers or words for the same topic. Which means some\\u00a0articles might use one word and other articles use the other word but they are all related and refer to the same subject.<br><br>Example:<br>Guide, Manual<br>Thesaurus:\\u00a0alias &quot;Guide&quot;,&quot;Manual&quot;<br>Better, Faster, Greater<br>Thesaurus:\\u00a0alias &quot;better&quot;,&quot;faster&quot;,&quot;greater&quot;<br><br><u><b>Expand:</b></u>\\u00a0is a one side direction synonym. It allows you to search the user expression and a\\u00a0better word. Sometimes you don&#39;t\\u00a0want to just replace the expression because the original expression could find articles but you have more content with a different synonym so you want them both.<br>Now if you only have two words in your rule why not using expand all? Because &quot;expand&quot; is <u>one way</u> while &quot;expand any&quot; we search for all the words in your rule.<br>If you use expand all with \\u00a0&quot;potato&quot;,&quot;Vegetable&quot;, when user enter one of those words, we will search both in the content<br>If you use expand\\u00a0with: \\u00a0&quot;potato&quot; to &quot;Vegetable&quot; \\u00a0when user enter potato we will search both BUT if user entered Vegetable we will not search for potato.\\u00a0<br><br>Popular Use Case:<br>Acronym. Users search for acronym where few articles exist but most of your content use the full word or vice versa.<br>Changed product name. Users search for a\\u00a0product name that has recently been changed. manual<br><br><u><b>Expand Any:</b></u> is searching all synonyms in your content as soon as one word is part of user expression.<br>Do not forget if an article meets more than one synonym of your rule, the weight will add up\\u00a0for each word we find in the article<br><br>Popular Use Case:<br>Your content has different qualifiers or words for the same topic. Which means some\\u00a0articles might use one word and other articles use the other word but they are all related and refer to the same subject.<br><br>Example:<br>Guide, Manual<br>Thesaurus:\\u00a0alias &quot;Guide&quot;,&quot;Manual&quot;<br>Better, Faster, Greater<br>Thesaurus:\\u00a0alias &quot;better&quot;,&quot;faster&quot;,&quot;greater&quot;<br><br><u><b>Expand:</b></u>\\u00a0is a one side direction synonym. It allows you to search the user expression and a\\u00a0better word. Sometimes you don&#39;t\\u00a0want to just replace the expression because the original expression could find articles but you have more content with a different synonym so you want them both.<br>Now if you only have two words in your rule why not using expand all? Because &quot;expand&quot; is <u>one way</u> while &quot;expand any&quot; we search for all the words in your rule.<br>If you use expand all with \\u00a0&quot;potato&quot;,&quot;Vegetable&quot;, when user enter one of those words, we will search both in the content<br>If you use expand\\u00a0with: \\u00a0&quot;potato&quot; to &quot;Vegetable&quot; \\u00a0when user enter potato we will search both BUT if user entered Vegetable we will not search for potato.\\u00a0<br><br>Popular Use Case:<br>Acronym. Users search for acronym where few articles exist but most of your content use the full word or vice versa.<br>Changed product name. Users search for a\\u00a0product name that has recently been changed. Some articles still refer to the old name but all recent article to the\\u00a0new name.<br><br>Example:<br>expand &quot;FY&quot; to &quot;\\\\&quot;Fiscal Year\\\\&quot;&quot;<br>If user search for &quot;FY&quot; we will search for both but if &quot;Fiscal Year&quot; is searched, we won&#39;t look for FY<br><br>expand &quot;ProductABC&quot; to &quot;ProductABCplus&quot;<br>If user search for &quot;ProductABC&quot; we will search for both but if &quot;ProductABCplus&quot; is searched, we won&#39;t look for &quot;ProductABC&quot;<br><br><span style=\\\"font-size: 14px;\\\"><u><b>Replace:</b></u></span> is used when you want to replace the user expression by something else.<br><br>Popular Use Case:<br>Visitors are searching my product name with a typo and this typo exists in one of my forum so the &quot;did you mean&quot; feature is not working and only\\u00a0show 1 article.<br><br>Product Name: BlackTea<br>User Typo: BlackTee<br>Thesaurus:\\u00a0replace &quot;BlackTee&quot; to &quot;BlackTea&quot;<br><br><b>Test:</b><br>Always test your synonyms prior to using them in production. You could be surprised by the results.<br>True Story: Customer added a thesaurus for the word &quot;clip&quot; and &quot;latch&quot; and while testing, customer saw that &quot;clip&quot; is also used with: video clip.<br><br><br><br>\\u00a0</div>     </div>   </body> </html>\"], \"sfisvisibleinapp\": [true], \"ka_attribute.url\": [\"/services/data/v34.0/sobjects/Best_Practice__ka/kA032000000PO7dCAG\"], \"sfdcarticletype\": [\"How To/Question\"], \"sfislatestversion\": [true], \"kav_details__c__html_stripped\": [\"Machine Learning has a big implication with Thesaurus (synonym) \\u00a0but sometimes you can help creating synonym by using the pipeline Thesaurus rule. \\n \\n There are 3 choices when creating thesaurus: \\n  \\n Note: The thesaurus rule is executed as soon as a match is found for one\\u00a0word \\n Example: User query = User Technical guide \\n Thesaurus = guide, manual \\n Coveo will search for: \\u00a0User Technical guide and User Technical manual \\n \\n Expand Any:  is searching all synonyms in your content as soon as one word is part of user expression. \\n Do not forget if an article meets more than one synonym of your rule, the weight will add up\\u00a0for each word we find in the article \\n \\n Popular Use Case: \\n Your content has different qualifiers or words for the same topic. Which means some\\u00a0articles might use one word and other articles use the other word but they are all related and refer to the same subject. \\n \\n Example: \\n Guide, Manual \\n Thesaurus:\\u00a0alias \\\"Guide\\\",\\\"Manual\\\" \\n Better, Faster, Greater \\n Thesaurus:\\u00a0alias \\\"better\\\",\\\"faster\\\",\\\"greater\\\" \\n \\n Expand: \\u00a0is a one side direction synonym. It allows you to search the user expression and a\\u00a0better word. Sometimes you don't\\u00a0want to just replace the expression because the original expression could find articles but you have more content with a different synonym so you want them both. \\n Now if you only have two words in your rule why not using expand all? Because \\\"expand\\\" is  one way  while \\\"expand any\\\" we search for all the words in your rule. \\n If you use expand all with \\u00a0\\\"potato\\\",\\\"Vegetable\\\", when user enter one of those words, we will search both in the content \\n If you use expand\\u00a0with: \\u00a0\\\"potato\\\" to \\\"Vegetable\\\" \\u00a0when user enter potato we will search both BUT if user entered Vegetable we will not search for potato.\\u00a0 \\n \\n Popular Use Case: \\n Acronym. Users search for acronym where few articles exist but most of your content use the full word or vice versa. \\n Changed product name. Users search for a\\u00a0product name that has recently been changed. Some articles still refer to the old name but all recent article to the\\u00a0new name. \\n \\n Example: \\n expand \\\"FY\\\" to \\\"\\\\\\\"Fiscal Year\\\\\\\"\\\" \\n If user search for \\\"FY\\\" we will search for both but if \\\"Fiscal Year\\\" is searched, we won't look for FY \\n \\n expand \\\"ProductABC\\\" to \\\"ProductABCplus\\\" \\n If user search for \\\"ProductABC\\\" we will search for both but if \\\"ProductABCplus\\\" is searched, we won't look for \\\"ProductABC\\\" \\n \\n Replace:  is used when you want to replace the user expression by something else. \\n \\n Popular Use Case: \\n Visitors are searching my product name with a typo and this typo exists in one of my forum so the \\\"did you mean\\\" feature is not working and only\\u00a0show 1 article. \\n \\n Product Name: BlackTea \\n User Typo: BlackTee \\n Thesaurus:\\u00a0replace \\\"BlackTee\\\" to \\\"BlackTea\\\" \\n \\n Test: \\n Always test your synonyms prior to using them in production. You could be surprised by the results. \\n True Story: Customer added a thesaurus for the word \\\"clip\\\" and \\\"latch\\\" and while testing, customer saw that \\\"clip\\\" is also used with: video clip. \\n \\n \\n \\n \\u00a0\"], \"sfarticlenumber\": [\"000002178\"], \"contenttype\": [\"binarydata\"], \"sfurlname\": [\"000002178\"], \"ka_id\": [\"kA032000000PO7dCAG\"], \"kav_datacategoryselections.datacategoryname\": [\"Usage_Analytics;How_To\"], \"coveo_url\": [\"https://na61.salesforce.com/kA032000000PO7d\"], \"kav_urlname\": [\"000002178\"], \"kav_dc_expanded_product\": [\"All;All|Usage Analytics\"], \"foldingcollection\": [\"5a60bc32a97dc3caed55321d11e79e53ee654ee6f01f1dadac0c334dcd77\"], \"kav_details__c\": [\"Machine Learning has a big implication with Thesaurus (synonym) \\u00a0but sometimes you can help creating synonym by using the pipeline Thesaurus rule.<br><br>There are 3 choices when creating thesaurus:<br><img alt=\\\"User-added image\\\" src=\\\"https://c.na61.content.force.com/servlet/rtaImage?eid=ka032000000HAHd&amp;feoid=00N32000002jMQL&amp;refid=0EM32000000VNrH\\\"></img><br>Note: The thesaurus rule is executed as soon as a match is found for one\\u00a0word<br>Example: User query = User Technical guide<br>Thesaurus = guide, manual<br>Coveo will search for: \\u00a0User Technical guide and User Technical manual<br><br><u><b>Expand Any:</b></u> is searching all synonyms in your content as soon as one word is part of user expression.<br>Do not forget if an article meets more than one synonym of your rule, the weight will add up\\u00a0for each word we find in the article<br><br>Popular Use Case:<br>Your content has different qualifiers or words for the same topic. Which means some\\u00a0articles might use one word and other articles use the other word but they are all related and refer to the same subject.<br><br>Example:<br>Guide, Manual<br>Thesaurus:\\u00a0alias &quot;Guide&quot;,&quot;Manual&quot;<br>Better, Faster, Greater<br>Thesaurus:\\u00a0alias &quot;better&quot;,&quot;faster&quot;,&quot;greater&quot;<br><br><u><b>Expand:</b></u>\\u00a0is a one side direction synonym. It allows you to search the user expression and a\\u00a0better word. Sometimes you don&#39;t\\u00a0want to just replace the expression because the original expression could find articles but you have more content with a different synonym so you want them both.<br>Now if you only have two words in your rule why not using expand all? Because &quot;expand&quot; is <u>one way</u> while &quot;expand any&quot; we search for all the words in your rule.<br>If you use expand all with \\u00a0&quot;potato&quot;,&quot;Vegetable&quot;, when user enter one of those words, we will search both in the content<br>If you use expand\\u00a0with: \\u00a0&quot;potato&quot; to &quot;Vegetable&quot; \\u00a0when user enter potato we will search both BUT if user entered Vegetable we will not search for potato.\\u00a0<br><br>Popular Use Case:<br>Acronym. challenges.</b></p>\\n\\n<p dir=\\\"ltr\\\"><b id=\\\"docs-internal-guid-b7e7ac33-c5c5-5988-4431-581cd62ccc88\\\">We use these informative conversations to continuously improve our products and services to better meet your needs. Below you will find a recap of the questions we asked, as well as the common themes that emerged from those conversations. </b></p>\\n\\n<h2 dir=\\\"ltr\\\"><b id=\\\"docs-internal-guid-b7e7ac33-c5c5-5988-4431-581cd62ccc88\\\">The questions that started the conversations</b></h2>\\n\\n<ol><li dir=\\\"ltr\\\">\\n\\t<h3 dir=\\\"ltr\\\"><b id=\\\"docs-internal-guid-b7e7ac33-c5c5-5988-4431-581cd62ccc88\\\">How are you measuring agent adoption / proficiency?</b></h3>\\n\\t</li></ol>\\n\\n<ul style=\\\"margin-left: 80px;\\\"><li dir=\\\"ltr\\\">\\n\\t<p dir=\\\"ltr\\\"><b id=\\\"docs-internal-guid-b7e7ac33-c5c5-5988-4431-581cd62ccc88\\\">Scattered information storing is a common challenge facing companies across the board. To combat this, implement a cohesive KCS workflow structure - One customer who recently launched a KCS pilot is already seeing positive impacts through measuring:</b></p>\\n\\n\\t<ul><li dir=\\\"ltr\\\">\\n\\t\\t<p dir=\\\"ltr\\\"><b id=\\\"docs-internal-guid-b7e7ac33-c5c5-5988-4431-581cd62ccc88\\\">AQI (Article Quality Index) which provides article confidence</b></p>\\n\\t\\t</li><li dir=\\\"ltr\\\">\\n\\t\\t<p dir=\\\"ltr\\\"><b id=\\\"docs-internal-guid-b7e7ac33-c5c5-5988-4431-581cd62ccc88\\\">Attachment rates (% of cases attached/associated to a support case)</b></p>\\n\\t\\t</li><li dir=\\\"ltr\\\">\\n\\t\\t<p dir=\\\"ltr\\\"><b id=\\\"docs-internal-guid-b7e7ac33-c5c5-5988-4431-581cd62ccc88\\\">article reuse \\u00a0(how often is an article being reused to solve a customer problem)</b></p>\\n\\t\\t</li></ul>\\n\\t</li><li dir=\\\"ltr\\\">\\n\\t<p dir=\\\"ltr\\\"><b id=\\\"docs-internal-guid-b7e7ac33-c5c5-5988-4431-581cd62ccc88\\\">Operationally, businesses are measuring content relevancy by measuring:</b></p>\\n\\n\\t<ul><li dir=\\\"ltr\\\">\\n\\t\\t<p dir=\\\"ltr\\\"><b id=\\\"docs-internal-guid-b7e7ac33-c5c5-5988-4431-581cd62ccc88\\\">Click-throughs and click ranks. \\u00a0</b></p>\\n\\t\\t</li><li dir=\\\"ltr\\\">\\n\\t\\t<p dir=\\\"ltr\\\"><b id=\\\"docs-internal-guid-b7e7ac33-c5c5-5988-4431-581cd62ccc88\\\">Time spent on a page or article</b></p>\\n\\t\\t</li><li dir=\\\"ltr\\\">\\n\\t\\t<p dir=\\\"ltr\\\"><b id=\\\"docs-internal-guid-b7e7ac33-c5c5-5988-4431-581cd62ccc88\\\">Engagement with site and content</b></p>\\n\\t\\t</li><li dir=\\\"ltr\\\">\\n\\t\\t<p dir=\\\"ltr\\\"><b id=\\\"docs-internal-guid-b7e7ac33-c5c5-5988-4431-581cd62ccc88\\\">Number of users</b></p>\\n\\t\\t</li></ul>\\n\\t</li><li dir=\\\"ltr\\\">\\n\\t<p dir=\\\"ltr\\\"><b id=\\\"docs-internal-guid-b7e7ac33-c5c5-5988-4431-581cd62ccc88\\\">Measuring the impact agent performance has on business continues be a struggle for many. It\\u2019s recognized that we have to change and focus performance measurement on outcomes at the team level. However, change is hard. As an industry we\\u2019ve been focused on activity based measures for so long, that the shift continues to be a challenge for most.</b></p>\\n\\t</li></ul>\\n\\n<ol start=\\\"2\\\"><li dir=\\\"ltr\\\">\\n\\t<h3 dir=\\\"ltr\\\"><b id=\\\"docs-internal-guid-b7e7ac33-c5c5-5988-4431-581cd62ccc88\\\">How are you driving Adoption to increase agent time to proficiency?</b></h3>\\n\\t</li></ol>\\n\\n<ul style=\\\"margin-left: 80px;\\\"><li dir=\\\"ltr\\\">\\n\\t<p dir=\\\"ltr\\\"><b id=\\\"docs-internal-guid-b7e7ac33-c5c5-5988-4431-581cd62ccc88\\\">Working with agents all over of the world can make it a challenge to implement change and drive adoption of new technology, operational practices, and workflows for fear of missing objectives established by executives. (see point #1)</b></p>\\n\\t</li><li dir=\\\"ltr\\\">\\n\\t<p dir=\\\"ltr\\\"><b id=\\\"docs-internal-guid-b7e7ac33-c5c5-5988-4431-581cd62ccc88\\\">Be careful about the incentives you do set: warns one customer who set out a 100% attachment rate of KB articles to cases. The result - agents wanting to meet their performance objectives (which are often tied to financial incentives), were not always attaching relevant content to their cases. \\u00a0This results in data integrity problems which defeats the whole purpose for linking cases &amp; articles.</b></p>\\n\\t</li><li dir=\\\"ltr\\\">\\n\\t<p dir=\\\"ltr\\\"><b id=\\\"docs-internal-guid-b7e7ac33-c5c5-5988-4431-581cd62ccc88\\\">Best Practice shows us that a link/attachment rate of 65%-80% is the industry benchmark. \\u00a0This may fluctuate with product/service release cycles, as fewer knowledgebase articles are immediately available when a new product or service is released. </b></p>\\n\\t</li><li dir=\\\"ltr\\\">\\n\\t<p dir=\\\"ltr\\\"><b id=\\\"docs-internal-guid-b7e7ac33-c5c5-5988-4431-581cd62ccc88\\\">Agents have much stronger adoption rates when they understand how their individual or team contribution is impacting the overall customer experience and organizational goals. Best Practice is to create cascading goals from the top down that enable the agent to see a direct correlation in their behaviour to meeting the corporate objectives. </b></p>\\n\\t</li></ul>\\n\\u00a0\\n\\n<ol start=\\\"3\\\"><li dir=\\\"ltr\\\">\\n\\t<h3 dir=\\\"ltr\\\"><b id=\\\"docs-internal-guid-b7e7ac33-c5c5-5988-4431-581cd62ccc88\\\">What metrics are you using to identify success signals and tell the story?</b></h3>\\n\\t</li></ol>\\n\\n<ul style=\\\"margin-left: 80px;\\\"><li dir=\\\"ltr\\\">\\n\\t<p dir=\\\"ltr\\\"><b id=\\\"docs-internal-guid-b7e7ac33-c5c5-5988-4431-581cd62ccc88\\\">Case Deflection, defined as the percentage of interactions that are taking place on a self-service community/portal that would have otherwise resulted in an assisted-service transaction in the contact center, \\u00a0is the most common theme for measuring business outcomes. Coveo products have the ability to accurately measure trends. This has significantly reduced effort for many who were previously calculating this manually in spreadsheets.</b></p>\\n\\t</li><li dir=\\\"ltr\\\">\\n\\t<p dir=\\\"ltr\\\"><b id=\\\"docs-internal-guid-b7e7ac33-c5c5-5988-4431-581cd62ccc88\\\">Leaders also ask, \\u201cHow strong is my content?\\u201d, \\u201cWhat am I missing?\\u201d \\u00a0to track other signals. </b></p>\\n\\n\\t<ul><li dir=\\\"ltr\\\">\\n\\t\\t<p dir=\\\"ltr\\\"><b id=\\\"docs-internal-guid-b7e7ac33-c5c5-5988-4431-581cd62ccc88\\\">Measurement Best Practices include metrics like:<br>\\t\\ta) Case Deflection &amp; Self Service Success - Understanding that both are important measures, but that there is a difference. \\u00a0Just because someone visits your portal, does not necessarily mean a case was deflected from an assisted service channel. \\u00a0</b><br>\\t\\t<b id=\\\"docs-internal-guid-b7e7ac33-c5c5-5988-4431-581cd62ccc88\\\">b) Content Gaps &amp; Top Content - This data helps facilitate the need for increased alignment and collaboration on content creation, and sharing. The data helps everyone understand the importance of a solid content management strategy.</b><br>\\t\\t<b id=\\\"docs-internal-guid-b7e7ac33-c5c5-5988-4431-581cd62ccc88\\\">c) Cases - New vs Known. \\u00a0Complete a study to analyze what percentage of the support cases coming into your assisted service channel get resolved with a known answer. \\u00a0This is what the industry refers to as \\u201cnew\\u201d vs \\u201cknown\\u201d. \\u00a0Understanding this will help you better identify how much \\u201cself-service\\u201d tools will be able to help.</b></p>\\n\\t\\t</li></ul>\\n\\t</li></ul>\\n\\n<h2 dir=\\\"ltr\\\"><b id=\\\"docs-internal-guid-b7e7ac33-c5c5-5988-4431-581cd62ccc88\\\">Themes</b></h2>\\n\\n<ol><li dir=\\\"ltr\\\">\\n\\t<p dir=\\\"ltr\\\"><b id=\\\"docs-internal-guid-b7e7ac33-c5c5-5988-4431-581cd62ccc88\\\">Relevant Content is critical. \\u00a0Leading enterprises are still struggling to empower agents with the right information because of inefficient knowledge sharing across devices and sources. By identifying content usage metrics that will point your organization toward the most relevant content, and creating agent performance metrics (linked to organizational performance) to increase those metrics, businesses will be able to guide content creation activities for the benefit of all. </b></p>\\n\\t</li></ol>\\n\\u00a0\\n\\n<ol start=\\\"2\\\"><li dir=\\\"ltr\\\">\\n\\t<p dir=\\\"ltr\\\"><b id=\\\"docs-internal-guid-b7e7ac33-c5c5-5988-4431-581cd62ccc88\\\"><a href=\\\"http://library.serviceinnovation.org/KCS_Kernel\\\" target=\\\"_blank\\\">KCS v6 (Knowledge Centered Service)</a> is an industry recognized best practice methodology. KCS was well known and being practiced by some, but was also very new to others. Coveo has the most KCS v6 certified employees of any organization, including several KCS Academy certified trainers who offer training and knowledge management related services for those interested in <a href=\\\"http://www.coveo.com/en/services/knowledge-management\\\" target=\\\"_blank\\\">learning more.</a></b></p>\\n\\t</li></ol>\\n\\n<ol start=\\\"3\\\"><li dir=\\\"ltr\\\">\\n\\t<p dir=\\\"ltr\\\"><b id=\\\"docs-internal-guid-b7e7ac33-c5c5-5988-4431-581cd62ccc88\\\">Improving agent metrics can be a long journey. Tieing adoption goals to overall business goals will guide a business\\u2019s path to success. Agents can be resistant to change when they can\\u2019t see the larger picture. Weaving temporary incentives that promote a customer-centric approach into agent workflow processes will help guide your entire organization towards the same goals. </b></p>\\n\\t</li></ol>\\n\\n<ol start=\\\"4\\\"><li dir=\\\"ltr\\\">\\n\\t<p dir=\\\"ltr\\\"><b id=\\\"docs-internal-guid-b7e7ac33-c5c5-5988-4431-581cd62ccc88\\\">A Customer-Centric Experience is Holistic. </b></p>\\n\\t</li></ol>\\n\\n<p dir=\\\"ltr\\\" style=\\\"margin-left: 40px;\\\"><b id=\\\"docs-internal-guid-b7e7ac33-c5c5-5988-4431-581cd62ccc88\\\">For a company to experience positive change, incentives can be woven into the companies\\u2019s culture. The Agent experience is one facet of the a comprehensive customer experience strategy - it\\u2019s can\\u2019t be treated in isolation. The self-service experience and agent experience now go hand in hand to deliver an overall Customer Experience.</b></p>\\n\\n<ol start=\\\"5\\\"><li dir=\\\"ltr\\\">\\n\\t<p dir=\\\"ltr\\\"><b id=\\\"docs-internal-guid-b7e7ac33-c5c5-5988-4431-581cd62ccc88\\\">Evaluate Messaging Capabilities to meet Customer Demands in Real Time </b></p>\\n\\t</li></ol>\\n\\n<p dir=\\\"ltr\\\" style=\\\"margin-left: 40px;\\\"><b id=\\\"docs-internal-guid-b7e7ac33-c5c5-5988-4431-581cd62ccc88\\\">It\\u2019s crucial to consistently evaluate the new tools available to agents to ensure your meeting customer expectations while balancing current organizational goals. \\u00a0Many are turning to chat as a cheaper, and more customer satisfying assisted service channel of operation. \\u00a0However it important to recognize that even though agents love it, since it\\u2019s always on, there is a higher rate of agent burnout. \\u00a0It was felt that the best practice was to rotate agents into a \\u201cchat\\u201d team for a period of time and then leverage other channel experiences - phone &amp; email to provide a balance.</b></p>\\n\\u00a0\\n\\n<h2 dir=\\\"ltr\\\"><b id=\\\"docs-internal-guid-b7e7ac33-c5c5-5988-4431-581cd62ccc88\\\">Additional Resources</b></h2>\\n\\n<p dir=\\\"ltr\\\"><b id=\\\"docs-internal-guid-b7e7ac33-c5c5-5988-4431-581cd62ccc88\\\">Below are a few links to some additional readings and resources we thought you may also enjoy.</b></p>\\n\\n<p dir=\\\"ltr\\\"><b id=\\\"docs-internal-guid-b7e7ac33-c5c5-5988-4431-581cd62ccc88\\\"><a href=\\\"http://www.coveo.com/en/resources/ebooks-white-papers/coveo-relevance-maturity-model\\\" target=\\\"_blank\\\">From Relevance Laggard to Leader: Becoming More Relevant to Your Customers, Communities and Staff</a></b></p>\\n\\n<p dir=\\\"ltr\\\"><b id=\\\"docs-internal-guid-b7e7ac33-c5c5-5988-4431-581cd62ccc88\\\"><a href=\\\"http://www.coveo.com/en/resources/ebooks-white-papers/your-roadmap-to-intelligent-assisted-support\\\" target=\\\"_blank\\\">Your Roadmap to Intelligent Assisted Support</a> </b></p>\\n\\n<p dir=\\\"ltr\\\"><b id=\\\"docs-internal-guid-b7e7ac33-c5c5-5988-4431-581cd62ccc88\\\"><a href=\\\"http://www.coveo.com/en/resources/ebooks-white-papers/the-state-of-knowledge-management-2014\\\" target=\\\"_blank\\\">TSIA Report: The Value of Unified Search in Customer Service</a></b></p>\\n\\n<p dir=\\\"ltr\\\"><b id=\\\"docs-internal-guid-b7e7ac33-c5c5-5988-4431-581cd62ccc88\\\"><a href=\\\"http://www.coveo.com/en/resources/ebooks-white-papers/the-five-essential-steps-to-plan-your-CX-transformation-the-strategy-report\\\" target=\\\"_blank\\\">Forrester whitepaper: The Five Essential Steps To Plan Your CX Transformation </a></b></p>\\n\\n<h3 dir=\\\"ltr\\\"><b id=\\\"docs-internal-guid-b7e7ac33-c5c5-5988-4431-581cd62ccc88\\\"><a href=\\\"http://www.coveo.com/en/resources/ebooks-white-papers/forrester-research-brief-cognitive-search-is-ready-to-rev-up-your-enterprise\\\" target=\\\"_blank\\\">Forrester Research Brief: Cognitive Search Is Ready To Rev Up Your Enterprise&#39;s IQ</a></b></h3>\\n\\n<p dir=\\\"ltr\\\">\\u00a0</p>\\n\\u00a0\\n\\n<p dir=\\\"ltr\\\">\\u00a0</p>\"], \"originalhtmlcharset\": [1200], \"coveo_connector_hasbinarydata\": [false], \"kav_lastpublisheddate\": [1510864299], \"sfsystemmodstamp\": [1516189553], \"ka_attribute.type\": [\"Best_Practice__ka\"], \"sfdcproduct\": [\"Usage Analytics\"], \"objecttypelabelplural\": [\"Best Practices\"], \"sftitle\": [\"Coveo Voice of the Customer Breakfast at Dreamforce 2017\"], \"kav_owner.id\": [\"00532000005IZovAAG\"], \"body\": [\"<html>   <body>     <div style=\\\"background-color: #fff;border: 2px solid #BBC5CC;border-radius: 4px;float: left;font-family: lato;margin-left: 15px;margin-right: 15px;margin-bottom: 4%;padding: 10px;width: 60%;\\\">       <div style=\\\"font-size: 1.5em;font-weight: 600;Padding-top: 30px;border-bottom: 1px solid #BBC5CC;\\\">         <div style=\\\"border-left: 1px solid #BBC5CC;border-top:
